sessions.title: .NET Best Practices and Workflows for Products with Multiple Teams

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Growing a company with multiple products and teams is always a challenge. To allow for code reusability, Age of Learning has brought and adapted classical .NET workflow and development patterns into our Unity development process. In this session, you'll learn about a number of .NET best practices, tools and workflows that will help you deal with Unity growing pains. These include the custom NuGet-based package management solution, the In-house IOC/Dependency Injection framework, the Model-View-Controller solution, the Asset bundle toolset, the Promises library used for asynchronous code (web requests etc.), and the Automation framework that builds unity projects, bundles, and nuget-driven features.

text.name: TALK_TEXT2
text.value:
- Development
- Business
- New and experienced growing teams

text.name: TALK_TEXT3
text.value: Audience will learn how to apply classical .NET development workflows and best practices into Unity development to allow for painless team and product growth.

speaker.title: Software Engineer
speaker.bio:
Leonid Umanskiy is a Software Engineer on the TAPS team at Age of Learning. TAPS represent: Technology, Architecture, Platforms and Standards. The team is responsible for building out platforms and tools that are used by 35+ Unity engineers. 

Leonid has 10+ years of experience building mobile, gaming, and e-learning products, with 7+ years of Unity development experience. Leonid worked on award-winning learning gaming products while working for multiple e-learning companies.

speaker.title: Director of Technology
speaker.bio: Devon Klompmaker is the Director of Technology for the TAPS (Technology, Architecture, Platforms and Standards) team at Age of Learning. The team is responsible for building out platforms and tools that are used by 35+ Unity engineers.  Devon has 11+ years of development leadership at multiple educational game companies.

sessions.title: 2D Tilemap: The Smart Way to Use Tilemaps and the Isometric Tilemap Preview

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Join technical evangelist, Liz Mercuri, to learn how to build a simple playable level using the 2D Tilemap and the Tilemap Collider 2D component. In this beginner session, Liz will demonstrate how creating Isometric, Hexagonal and regular Tilemaps, Palettes and RuleTiles enables you to iterate faster. You'll also discover how you can bring life to your scene by creating animated tiles. Finally, you will see how to apply behavior to your tiles using scripts.

speaker.title: Technical Evangelist
speaker.bio: Alessia is a Technical Evangelist at Unity. She started developing small games at game jams and hackathons, and she joined Unity in 2017 to develop and demonstrate small projects, and share tips about working with Unity at conferences and meet-ups around the world. As a gamer, she is passionate about immersive story-based adventures and anything experimental.

sessions.title: 3D World Building with ProCore: Faster, More Effective Workflows

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Come learn how to create playable levels quickly and with precisely using ProBuilder and ProGrids in Unity. You'll see how you can use Polybrush to enhance your designs and how to iterate levels quicker by improving the efficiency of your workflows. Specifically, some of the workflows we'll cover will be moving assets between 3D software packages and Unity and using ProCore with lighting, dynamic objects and prefabs.

speaker.title: AR/VR Evangelist
speaker.bio: Dan is an AR/VR evangelist at Unity Technologies. He has been working in game development for several years as a developer with a recent focus in VR. He's excited to help others explore the forefront of new and emergent technologies and the many unique opportunities they present.

sessions.title: A Tale Of Ten SDKs: Cross-Platform Development Best Practices

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Your goal of delivering your game to as many players as possible is best served by submitting it to every storefront possible. But when you submit to a large number of platforms, you are also going to have to keep track of a multitude of requirements and details. In this session, you'll learn strategies for porting your game to multiple platforms efficiently, along with tips for venturing into cross-platform console development. You'll also see how Night School Studio handled porting Oxenfree to ten platforms with their own bare hands, including a look at their GameInstancing and BuildManager systems built on top of Unity.

text.name: TALK_TEXT2
text.value: Developers and Publishers who are working on Unity games that target a variety of platforms.

text.name: TALK_TEXT3
text.value: Developers will come away with new strategies for porting their Unity game to multiple platforms without skipping a beat. They'll also learn about some of Night School Studio's methods for organizing platform-specific functionality, such as their GameInstancing and BuildManager systems.

speaker.title: Lead Engineer
speaker.bio: Bryant Cannon has been the lead engineer at Night School Studio since the company was founded in 2014 and a Unity programmer in the industry since 2009. He holds a 2010 degree in Interactive Entertainment from the USC School of Cinematic Arts. Bryant was the sole engineer on the studio's debut game, Oxenfree, and he ported the game to 8 of the 10 platforms that the game is currently sold on. Bryant continues to lead the development team on their upcoming release, Afterparty.

sessions.title: A Three-Course Meal in Procedural Content Generation

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: In this session we will show how we could harness the power of procedural content generation to deliver a three-course meal. First, you will learn how to create a diversity of enemies and adapt them according to the player's skill-level with the help of evolutionary algorithms. Second, you will learn how to create dungeons and islands effectively using binary space partitioning. Finally, you will learn how to create levels imitating a designer's style via n-grams.

text.name: TALK_TEXT2
text.value:
Development & Creative

Programmers, Developers, Creatives, and Tech Leads looking for ways to harness the power of procedural content generation into their projects

text.name: TALK_TEXT3
text.value:
For the creatives and tech leads: the audience will get to see how procedural content generation could help them improve their projects, specially when we are indie developers and need to find cost-effective ways to develop hours of play, and an illustration on how to approach some algorithms.

Developers: they'll learn the basis of 3 different algorithms (evolutionary algorithm, BSP trees, n-grams), their data structures, and how to implement them in Unity.

speaker.title: AI / Gameplay Programmer
speaker.bio: Jorge Palacios is a freelance game developer with more than over seven years' professional experience, five of which were focused on Unity. From generalist to lead programmer, Jorge has worked with clients around the world. He has also both given talks and written books on the subject of AI. (You can find his works on Unity AI work here: https://www.packtpub.com/books/info/authors/jorge-palacios.) Jorge went from Global Game Jam (Caracas) attendee in 2008 to main organizer (Caracas) in 2016. Because he believes in the giving back to the community, all talks at grassroots events were given for free. Jorge holds a B.Sc. degree in Computer Science.

sessions.title: Accelerating Disruption in the Automotive Industry with Unity

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Traditional processes to design, manufacture, market, sell and maintain cars are being disrupted through the use of AR/VR/MR. Using Unity's multi-hardware deployment platform, software developers can now deliver the perfect tools for Automotive brands to optimize or rethink various processes that have remained unchanged for years. During this intermediate-level session, you will see examples of globally deployed configurators by a luxury-vehicle brand, CAD tracking of a real engine with AR developed for training and maintenance purposes, and how software modularity permits easy scalability and multiple use cases.

speaker.title: Co-founder, Business Catalyst
speaker.bio: David is co-founder and business catalyst for Visionaries 777. His first experience with interactive technologies came from co-designing and programming media facades with LED DMX-driven systems across Asia, the Middle East and Latin America. He resides in Hong Kong, where he leads strategic growth partnerships and key customer relations.

speaker.title: Co-founder, Project Lead
speaker.bio: Frantz is a co-founder and project leader for the automotive department in Visionaries 777. He has a master's degree in Interaction Design with a focus on Augmented Reality. His final degree project, based on AR, and was selected for presentation at SIGGRAPH 2009 (New Orleans) and SIGGRAPH Asia 2009 (Yokohama). After his studies, he joined LEGO's concept lab, in an R&D role that explored and prototyped several innovative concepts primarily based on AR that helped envision the future of play experience. He now leads teams working on interactive software tools deployed globally by brands such as BMW and Infiniti.

sessions.title: Adding Love to an API (or How to Expose C++ in Unity)

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Tool developers have the power to make it easier for game developers to create wonderful things. In this talk, Shawn Laptiste, will show other tool developers methods to expose C/C++ libraries to Unity developers so that the functionality and ease-of-use resemble that of built-in Unity functionality.

text.name: TALK_TEXT2
text.value: The intended audience for this talk includes game/tools developers who wish to integrate external C/C++ libraries within their Unity games giving them the ability to leverage already existing code instead of translating it to C#.

text.name: TALK_TEXT3
text.value:
Part 1: C/C++ in Unity
* Using SWIG to convert C++ API to C# API
* Calling C# delegates from C++
Part 2: Unity Editor
* Creating Unity PropertyDrawers and Inspectors
* Providing in-editor hooks

speaker.title: Software Developer - Game Integrations
speaker.bio: Shawn Laptiste is known for his laugh, having an affinity for beautiful sounds, and caring about clean code (though not necessarily in that order). With almost two decades of tinkering in computer music and approximately 15 years in professional software development, his experience is a Venn diagram with audio software at its intersection. His work ranges from working on AAA gaming titles (Ubisoft Montreal's Rainbow Six Siege) to working on electronic warfare systems for flight simulators (CAE).

sessions.title: Advantages of 2D Tilemaps for Mobile Games

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: In this session, Sophia Clarke, a software engineer in Unity's Release QA team, will explain the advantages of using 2D Tilemaps for creating mobile games. You'll leave the session knowing what Tilemaps are and when to use them, and also get an overview of the workflow, best practices for working with textures, and how to optimize performance. If you're new to Tilemaps, or if you've used Tilemaps before but would like to learn some best practices for mobile, this talk will be useful to you.

speaker.title: Software Engineer
speaker.bio: As a software engineer in Unity's Release QA team, Sophia is responsible for overseeing and executing alpha and beta testing of Unity, helping to ensure high standards across the QA organization and creating and maintaining tools for reporting and testing. In 2018, she was featured on the GamesIndustry.biz Top 100 Future Talent list, and she had a game featured at AMaze Berlin.

sessions.title: AEC Demo: From Unity to Reality

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Come to this advanced session to hear two real-life AEC industry stories in which Unity added value. The first illustrates how Unity brought a $40M commercial project to life for a live demo, which ultimately shed light on factors that impacted the design. The second shows how, with the help of ProBuilder and AR, Unity was used to calculate costs and save 20% on a personal renovation project.

speaker.title: Head of Global Evangelism
speaker.bio: Carl Callewaert finds his passion in supporting and teaching developers around the world. His background in architecture and virtual reality led him to join the games industry and create AR and VR experiences for several serious game companies. His enthusiasm for 3D, VR/AR and gaming builds upon 10 years of production and evangelism experience. Prior to Unity, Carl worked for The Canadian Space Agency, Measurand, Autodesk Education and on a number of AAA and indie games.

sessions.title: AI for Behavior: How Advanced Research Will Revolutionize the Way You Create

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: The Behavior Planner is a new AI-driven system created by Unity Labs that gives a game object the ability to reason on how it should act, based on predetermined choice criteria in an authoring flow that can be used for NPCs, game design feedback, player tutorials and more. Part feature breakdown and part AI master class, come to this session to hear Unity's Trevor Santarra and Nicolas Meuleau describe the research powering this capability and the state-of-the-art set of algorithms that power the underlying planning system.

speaker.title: Research Engineer, AI
speaker.bio: Trevor is a Research Engineer at Unity Labs, creating tools for automated behavior planning. Before Unity, he was a graduate student at the University of California – Santa Cruz, where he investigated information-theoretic strategies for coordinating multi-agent teams. Straddling the divide between industrial and academic research, Trevor strives to bring state-of-the-art approaches to game AI.

speaker.title: Director of AI Research
speaker.bio: Nicolas is a researcher in AI with expertise in decision-making, automated planning, and machine learning. During his 25-year career, he has developed and deployed autonomous decision systems for a variety of application domains, including space, aeronautics, automotive and finance. He recently joined Unity as Director of AI Research to promote the development of next-generation AI tools in Unity.

sessions.title: An RTS in 4 Hours

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Despite the title, this session is not so much about developing Real Time Strategy (RTS) games as it is about how to how to focus and finish any project.  It's about how to avoid letting things like squirrels, perfection and kitchen sinks distract you. Along the way, you will learn a method for reducing mega ideas into mini game-jams and get tips and methods to stay focused. You'll also hear the story of how Dan Sagmiller developed an RTS in four hours. What's more, the game was complete with an AI enemy who was building bases (and sending ever-growing units to attack), resources, sort of a fog of war, a functional tech tree and more.  All in 3D, with explosions, battles and a 3D map.

text.name: TALK_TEXT2
text.value:
Creative
Developers

text.name: TALK_TEXT3
text.value: Audience members should be able to identify what is slowing them down or just plain blocking them; mentally, architecturally and in design.

text.name: TALK_TEXT4
text.value:
Online course where I created it in 4 hours including all training and explanations for every line of code.
http://www.lynda.com/Unity-tutorials/Welcome/427923/479691-4.html

speaker.title: SR XR Solutions Architect
speaker.bio: Dan Sagmiller is a senior-level programmer with almost 20 years of experience. He is a regular speaker, the author of two books, and the teacher of two Lynda courses — all on the subject of Unity. Dan was awarded the Microsoft MVP from 2016 to 2018 for his work in Unity, and he even has a Unity tattoo.

sessions.title: AR Best Practices

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Get an overview of what it takes to build a mobile AR app using ARCore or ARKit. This session could be your first step toward unlocking new categories of apps and games and new opportunities to reach millions of iOS and Android users. You'll leave with an overview of best practices for rendering, interaction and error handling. The session is aimed at handheld-AR developers at a beginning to intermediate level.

speaker.title: AR/VR Evangelist
speaker.bio: Dan is an AR / VR evangelist at Unity Technologies. He has been working in game development for several years as a developer with a recent focus in VR. He's excited to help others explore the forefront of new and emergent technologies and the many unique opportunities they present.

sessions.title: Autonomous Vehicle Development with Unity

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: In this intermediate-level session, Jose De Oliveira, who heads up Unity's Autonomous Vehicles Strategy, will reveal our roadmap to leverage the leading 3D real-time rendering engine for creating a simulation and visualization framework for automotive projects. In particular, he will focus on how Unity is ideal for supporting the development of autonomous vehicle technologies and processes.

speaker.title: Principal Engineer, Lead of Autonomous Vehicles Strategy
speaker.bio: Jose leads Unity's autonomous vehicles strategies, part of our Industrial initiatives. He joined Unity's Machine Learning team in May 2017, and works out of our office in Bellevue, WA. Prior to Unity, he spent 17 years at Microsoft on projects ranging from real-time communications to enterprise security systems. He started his Machine Learning career working on content-filtering solutions for Family Safety back in 2006. He headed the team that delivered the first anti-phishing features (SmartScreen) in IE 7. Later, he joined Bing Ads, where he led the development of paid search relevance models on mobile devices. In his last two years at Microsoft, he worked on Bing Maps, developing geospatial and map-creation technology, and continued that work during almost two years at Uber.

sessions.title: AutoTech: to be revealed
Baymax Dreams: Graphics, Lighting and FX for Real-Time Animation

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: In this advanced session, John Parsaie, a Unity graphics expert, will walk attendees through best practices in shading and real-time lighting for episodic animation.

speaker.title: Graphics Software Engineer
speaker.bio: John is a Graphics Engineer at Unity, focused on production-oriented efforts with the Made with Unity team. He works closely with creators and studios to advance the graphical fidelity of showcased Unity productions such as ADAM: 2 & 3 and "Baymax Dreams." After developing new rendering features for specific projects, John shepherds them back to the Unity engine for all users to benefit. When not pushing pixels, John enjoys exploring all things tangible and analog in an effort to find balance with his digital passion.

speaker.title: Producer
speaker.bio: Sarah is a technical producer at Unity Technologies and an enthusiastic member of the developer community. She spends much of her time exploring tools and techniques for content creation, furthering her mission to empower developers and artists to create stunning real-time experiences. Prior to Unity, she built software at VR companies Pixvana and WorldViz. Sarah holds a Bachelor’s degree in Electrical Engineering from the University of California at Santa Barbara.

sessions.title: Best Practices for Fast Game Design in Unity

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: In this expert talk, Renaud Forestié, Gameloft Montreal's Gameplay Director, reveals how his team of five can design a mobile game in just two to fourteen days by focusing on the game-feel and experience. Renaud will share Gameloft's design best practices for speeding up and improving the quality of design iterations. You'll leave the session with an overview of a process for creating compelling and memorable experiences in a very short timeframe while gaining valuable insight into your game's potential.

text.name: TALK_TEXT2
text.value: The talk is mainly aimed at creatives and development teams involved or interested in prototyping, but can also be interesting for business people as it'll cover some of the more strategic reasons behind fast iteration in games.

text.name: TALK_TEXT3
text.value: They'll have learned how they can replicate our methods and successes using simple techniques, and how and where to put the focus and effort when creating a prototype to maximize its potential.

text.name: TALK_TEXT4
text.value: This talk would be an updated version of a talk I did a few months back at Unity Developer Day Montreal, which was 40 min only, while this one would include a bit more tips and detailed examples.

speaker.title: Gameplay Director
speaker.bio: Whether he's working on a game, a website, a mobile app, or an illustration, Renaud always focuses on the final user experience (UX) and tries to design creative and useful interactions. Building on 15 years spent crafting a wide array of products, including humanitarian-crisis apps for NGOs, tech-startup apps, innovative art experiences, and the bestselling Corgi Engine for the Unity Asset Store. Renaud runs More Mountains, a one-man studio dealing in UX and games, with clients such as Warner Bros and Orange. He's also a UX/UI Google Expert, and a Gameplay Director at Gameloft Montreal.

sessions.title: Best Practices for Scalable & Real-Time Multiplayer Games

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Creating great real-time multiplayer games, which are both performant and scalable, requires a lot of knowledge and experience. Take a shortcut! In this intermediate-level session, join the specialists from Multiplay, a Unity company, to learn key concepts and lessons for your next real-time multiplayer game.

speaker.title: Lead Solutions Engineer
speaker.bio: With over 17 years' experience as an engineer in hosting and gaming, Larry works with game engineers from  around the world to design and implement game-server hosting solutions that are focused on the genre-specific gamer experiences. Learn how he and his team have overcome some of the toughest challenges in scaling multiplayer games – from 4-player co-ops to 100-player battle royale games.

speaker.title: Head of Sales
speaker.bio: Matthew heads up the Sales, Client & Solutions teams at Multiplay, a Unity company. In this role, he leads engagements with game studios around the world to plan and design robust hosting infrastructure for their multiplayer games. Matthew has over 14 years' experience in hosting and gaming and has been instrumental in driving Multiplay's reputation as the go-to game-server hosting specialist.

sessions.title: Best Practices for Shader Graph

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: With Shader Graph in Unity 2018, creating powerful and beautiful shaders has never been easier. But with great power, comes great responsibility. This intermediate-level session will explore best practices for rendering performance and shader creation workflow. We'll cover what happens under the hood, share tips to avoid common pitfalls, and highlight what to look for as Shader Graph readies for prime-time release in the near future.

speaker.title: Developer Relations Engineer
speaker.bio: For many years, Charles helped unblock and accelerate Xbox game development across the industry. He now works with Unity's Enterprise Support team, helping developers achieve their Unity performance goals.

sessions.title: Better Unity Scripting with Rider

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Rider is a cross platform C# script editor that really understands Unity. Let's take a look at how it can make you a better, more productive Unity developer. We'll see how to get started (spoiler: it's really easy) and how Rider's deep understanding of your project will help you navigate your codebase quicker, edit your Unity scripts smarter, debug your project (even on devices) run tests, and find and fix issues before they cause problems at runtime. This session will give you all the best tips and tricks that will make Rider your favorite new script editor for Unity.

speaker.title: Technical Evangelist
speaker.bio: Matt Ellis is a developer advocate at JetBrains. He has spent 20 years shipping software and currently works with language tooling, having fun with plugins, abstract syntax trees and source code analysis. He owns and contributes to various open source projects, and believes in the open closed principle.

sessions.title: Beyond ArchViz: Discovering the value in interactivity

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Learn how Mortenson, one of the world's largest construction companies, has developed their approach to facilitating design, training personnel, and engaging customers through immersive simulations. By comparing some of their earlier projects to their most recent work, you'll see how they have learned to use Unity to generate value for major brands, and begin to explore their vision for the future of the medium.

speaker.title: VR Developer
speaker.bio: Will was pursuing his masters of architecture at the University of Minnesota when he discovered virtual reality (VR) and its potential to impact design and construction. He began researching real-world applications of the medium with Mortenson Construction, which is headquartered in Minneapolis and has an ongoing partnership with the university. He's now an Emerging Technologies Developer at Mortenson, growing a division focused on applying emerging technology to Mortenson's customers' businesses. His passion for architecture, programming, and technologies like virtual reality led him to explore how the intersection of these fields can positively impact the rapidly changing building industry.

speaker.title: Immersive Technology Developer
speaker.bio: Marc is an Emerging Technologies Developer for Mortenson Construction and works out of their Seattle, WA office. In this role, he's responsible for the company's use of augmented and virtual reality and is looking to push the industry forward one project at a time through stunning visuals and compelling interactions. Kinsman was previously an integrated construction coordinator for the firm and was responsible for implementation and coordination of virtual design and construction processes throughout projects. He has a bachelor's degree in construction management from the University of Washington, where his studies included a heavy emphasis on BIM/VDC, design build and building performance analysis.

sessions.title: BMW VR Lab: Cross-Discipline XR Experiences for Automotive

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Since 2015, the BMW TV2i-VR Lab has been creating XR experiences to enhance internal processes across multiple departments. This overview session focuses on how their global cross-discipline team employs Unity as a platform for interactive digital experiences and collaborative development, and where it fits into various workflows. They will highlight some key projects and use cases they built in-house, including using Unity for BMW marketing, logistics training procedures, production layout and planning, machine learning training, and workflow simulations.

text.name: TALK_TEXT2
text.value:
-Auto Tech Industry
-VR for Business Interests
-Business
-Design + Development

text.name: TALK_TEXT3
text.value: Our talk will include case studies of XR experiences design for Automotive Industry, with a focus on internal company workflows. Audiences will get an understanding of the opportunities developing with Unity in-house offers for large scale companies, and how Unity and XR can be utilised as more then a method for marketing/visualisation in the automotive sector, but as a valuable tool for enhancing traditional work practises. The talk will highlight current projects from the BMW VR Lab and spotlight future project directions.

text.name: TALK_TEXT4
text.value: This talk would best fit the Unity Auto Tech Summit, as witnessed in Berlin 2018.

speaker.title: Design Team Lead (TV2i)
speaker.bio:
Based in Munich, Australian designer Dylan Sheppard leads the BMW TV-2i VR Lab design team, supporting a wide range of projects across digital experience design. He brings a broad skill set to BMW through his background in product design, and his work with start-ups, design consultancies and international brands. His work has been recognized by the Design Institute of Australia, receiving the DIA Professional Achievement Award in 2016. Dylan was also the recipient of the DIA's 2017 Industrial Design Graduate of the Year and the 2017 Australian State Design Graduate Award. 

As well, Dylan's projects have continued to gain international recognition, including being shortlisted for the Braun International Design Prize and featured in international design publications. He was a guest speaker at the 2017 Global Youth Leadership Summit in Hong Kong.

speaker.title: VR Content Creator
speaker.bio:
Peter studied industrial design and for the last year has been working in the VR Lab at BMW in Munich, leading development in use cases for BMW marketing, logistics training procedures, production layout and planning and workflow simulations. 

As the touchpoint for use-case development with Unity, Peter manages the workflow between the inter-departmental planning stages through to the rollout of final applications for BMW plants internationally. Peter continues to support VR projects across BMW by overseeing the planning and installation of "satellite" VR labs at multiple plants, supporting digitization and new technology rollouts across the company's entire production network.

speaker.title: VR Content Creator and BIM Specialist
speaker.bio: Frieder studied civil engineering in Munich and his focus lies in developing and implementing building information modeling (BIM) methods in Unity. At BMW, he works with Unity to bring collaborative digital factory design into VR.

speaker.title: Research Associate (Virtual Reality at BMW)
speaker.bio:
Anirudh leads the VR development team at BMW VRLab and holds an M.Sc degree in Architectural Informatics from Technical University of Munich (TUM). He is mainly involved in managing the development and rollout of VR applications, ranging from process simulations to interactive layout planning tools. With his background in the construction industry, he leads the development of building informatics-backed interactive layout planning of BMW's production facilities.

As one of the founding members of the BMW VR Lab, he is active in expanding the avenues for VR at BMW and coordinates with various departments to ideate new applications for VR in standard workflows. In his current capacity, Anirudh is researching collaborative layout planning in VR and actively publishing on developments.

sessions.title: Bringing Supernatural Thriller, "Oxenfree" to Nintendo Switch

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: In this intermediate session, you'll find out what Night School Studio learned from their plunge into the Nintendo Switch delivering their debut branching-narrative adventure game, "Oxenfree," in just a few months with a single programmer using Unity. The studio's lead engineer, Bryant Cannon, will cover tips and tricks for getting the most out of the Nintendo Switch's innovative design features. He will also guide you on how to prepare for the Nintendo Switch early in the development process and how to avoid common technical speed bumps.

speaker.title: Lead Developer
speaker.bio: Bryant Cannon has been the lead engineer at Night School Studio since the company was founded in 2014 and a Unity programmer in the industry since 2009. He holds a 2010 degree in Interactive Entertainment from the USC School of Cinematic Arts. Bryant was the sole engineer on the studio's debut game, Oxenfree, and leads a small engineering team on the upcoming adventure game, Afterparty.

sessions.title: Building Organic 2D Worlds with SpriteShape

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: SpriteShape brings organic 2D world-building to Unity. This session will give you an overview the assets and components of SpriteShape. Next, you will learn how you can apply this feature to a shape-based level layout. Finally, we will discover how you can access the underlying spline data to create engaging and visually appealing real-time results.

speaker.title: Technical Product Manager, 2D
speaker.bio: Rustum Scammell has been making games for more than 10 years. He owns Craft Colony, a game production & consulting company. He is a games technology generalist and takes a holistic approach to game development. He has been developing in Unity since 2009. Rus is an MSC Malaysia Intellectual Property Creators Challenge (IPCC) winner. In 2012, he released Penyu the Turtle, a top‐down shooter for iOS. He also launched and managed Malaysia’s first online portal for game assets. Previously, he was Technical Art Director at Big Bad Robots and Senior 3D Artist at GameBrains.

sessions.title: Building the Next Generation of Xbox Avatars with Unity

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: With the launch of Xbox Avatars, this team will share the vision, design and technical work that brought the latest generation of avatars to life. In this intermediate-level session, learn how they leveraged and integrated multiple Unity features like Mecanim and Physics support to create inclusive, expressive and creative avatars. They'll show how they used the Unity Editor UI to build a content pipeline that allowed them to create everything from a ring to prosthetic limbs to wheelchairs and unicorns. Discover how they overcame the challenges of integrating this rich system into the Xbox ecosystem, including porting the previous Avatar engine for backward-compatibility mode.

speaker.title: Software Engineer
speaker.bio: Jingyi is a software developer working on Xbox Avatars and has been at Microsoft for her entire career. She joined the team when they brought the last-generation Avatar back to Xbox and they are now shipping the next generation. Jingyi enjoys casual platformers and funny co-op games like Ori and Overcooked.

speaker.title: Software Engineer
speaker.bio: Andy is a software developer working on Xbox Avatars. He started at Microsoft in early 2016 and specializes in Unity. There's probably only one person with blue hair on the stage, and that's Andy.

speaker.title: Lead Animator
speaker.bio: Noel is an animator with experience in feature films and games like Shrek and Portal 2. You may find him staring at you. It's okay, he is just studying your "character attributes." Sounds creepy, but really he is harmless and, when approached, he will engage with you in an animated fashion.

sessions.title: C# Job System + ECS Usage and Demo with Intel

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: This intermediate-level session will showcase examples of the C# Job System + ECS (Entity Component System), and explain how to take advantage of this new Unity feature to optimize your CPU usage.

speaker.title: Graphics and Multicore Developer Relations Engineer
speaker.bio: Issam is a Graphics and Multicore Developer Relations Engineer at Intel. He has worked in the game industry for the last 14 years, contributing to games and engines for handheld, consoles and PC.

sessions.title: Capturing Real-World Materials for Real-Time Development

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Two Unity 3D content-creation experts will demonstrate how to capture real-world materials, such as leather, fabrics, plastics, rubber and non-reflective metals – using low-cost, easily-accessible photography equipment and the photometric stereo technique – and then bring them into Unity for developing automotive applications.

speaker.title: Senior Solutions Developer, Automotive
speaker.bio: Luc is a Senior Solutions Developer at Unity, based in Montreal, Canada. Working in the movie and architecture industries for over 13 years, he has contributed to the fields of photorealistic rendering, FBX format, virtual movie sets, Unity Services and 3D content-creation tools.

speaker.title: Technical Artist
speaker.bio: Camille is a Technical Artist specialized in photometry and she is currently working on Unity's automotive material library. She joined Unity in Montreal in March 2018 as an intern and has since worked on two real-time Lexus teasers with the Automotive and Brand & Design teams. Fresh out of school, she studied 3D and video game development.

sessions.title: CI/CD and User Interaction Testing for Mobile

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Learn how to effectively implement CI/CD for mobile projects using Unity's command line, Jenkins, Python and Fastlane to create build artifacts for various mobile platforms including iOS and Android. Some topics will include fully automating the certificate and provisioning profile management process for iOS, as well as handling various intricacies like pre-build and post-build tasks for each initiative/project running within any part of the organization. Additionally, Age of Learning will discuss details of UI Testing with Unity mobile applications and explain how ABCmouse uses sockets to interface between Python-scripted UI tests and Unity application(s) in conjunction with Appium to simulate native user interactions within the aforementioned CI/CD pipeline.

speaker.title: Vice President, Mobile Engineering
speaker.bio: Current VP of Mobile Engineering at Age of Learning with more than 19 years of software and game/app development experience, including six startups. More than seven self-published apps/games currently in the App Store as well as named inventor on multiple mobile related patents. Peter has been in an active love affair with Unity since 2011.

speaker.title: Senior DevOps Engineer
speaker.bio: Aditya currently plays a lead role in end to end automation of mobile build and release processes at Age of Learning. He is a passionate DevOps Leader with 8+ years of engineering experience in mobile and desktop process automation using Unity, Kubernetes, Docker and AWS.

sessions.title: CocoVR: Pixar Storytelling in an Interactive, Multiplayer World

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Pixar's virtual reality debut, "Coco VR," takes the adventure, beautiful artwork and narrative of the Disney-Pixar film, "Coco," into a whole new dimension. Complete with selfie machines, cable cars, live music, skull painting, art museums, and more, the audience enjoys a one-of-a-kind social experience together with friends and family.  A testament to the power of transmedia, this piece is both a feat of storytelling prowess and an ambitious technical accomplishment. Come hear Pixar and Magnopus dive into the details of how they approached the design challenges and listen to their predictions for immersive storytelling in the years to come.

speaker.title: Co-founder
speaker.bio: The Co-Founder and CEO of Magnopus, Ben Grossmann is an Emmy and Oscar-winning visual effects supervisor and VR Director whose resume includes films like JJ Abrams' "Star Trek Into Darkness," Martin Scorsese's "Hugo," Tim Burton's "Alice in Wonderland," and dozens more. With a decade-plus of experience in media and entertainment, Ben has also worked on next-gen projects like the Universal Studios' Forbidden Journey theme park ride for the Harry Potter franchise and, via Magnopus, on the Emmy-nominated VR experience "Mission: ISS," a game-engine powered recreation of the International Space Station, developed in collaboration with NASA, the European Space Agency, Oculus and others. Ben is a member of the Academy of Motion Pictures Arts and Sciences, the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences, and the Visual Effects Society.

speaker.title: Supervising Technical Director
speaker.bio: John Halstead began his career at Pixar Animation Studios in June 2000.  Brought on for the Academy Award®-winning, "Finding Nemo," Halstead worked on sets-modeling and articulation and effects for the film.  Halstead continued as sets technical lead for the Golden Globe®-winning feature, "Cars," and as sets supervisor on another Oscar®-winner, "Up," and "Cars 2." He was most recently the supervising technical director on Disney•Pixar's feature film, "Finding Dory."

speaker.title: Development Supervisor
speaker.bio: Kalan Ray is a VR Director and Development Supervisor at Magnopus and co-founder of VKTRY Creative Studios. He is an animator, programmer, and designer whose work has contributed to the Emmy-Nominated interactive experience Mission:ISS, Pixar’s Coco VR, Blade Runner 2049: Memory Lab, as well as Martin Scorsese's The Audition, and CNNVR. An expert in rapid prototyping and previsualization, Kalan has supervised and creatively contributed to development in feature films, television, commercials, music videos, theme park rides, video games, and VR experiences. His film credits include The Jungle Book, Fantastic 4, Star Trek: Beyond, at many prestigious visual effects companies, including DreamWorks, Pixomondo, and Bad Robot. A California native, Kalan was born and raised in Barstow, and holds a degree in Linguistics from the University of California at Long Beach.

sessions.title: Create Amazing Visual Effects with the Visual Effects Graph

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: The Visual Effects Graph gives artists of all experience levels the power to create amazing visual effects. In this intermediate-level session, Vlad Neykov and Julien Fryer from our development team will give you a sneak peek into how to generate millions of GPU-based particles in real-time using the Visual Effects Graph's toolset.

sessions.title: Creating Adaptive Gaming Experiences

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: In this intermediate-level session, learn how to adapt your game for optimal and personalized user experiences, from onboarding throughout the entire gameplay. Device performance directly affects how enjoyable your game is. Unity LiveTune adjusts your content dynamically for every device to achieve optimal quality and performance so you can provide the best playing experiences across 50,000+ mobile device models and keep the players engaged.

speaker.title: Product Manager, Live Tune
speaker.bio: Elie Noune is the product manager for LiveTune, a data-driven performance optimization product being developed by Unity Analytics. At Unity, Elie's focus has been around using data to help developers understand and solve for device fragmentation, with products like Device Intelligence and now LiveTune. Elie graduated from the American University of Beirut and Stanford University with a BS and MS in Electrical Engineering.

speaker.title: Product Manager, Analytics
speaker.bio: At Unity, Lauren is the Head of the Adaptive Onboarding team in Developer Analytics. Prior to Unity, she worked as an analytics consultant, helping studios use data to increase retention and monetization of their players. She has over 10 years' experience in gaming, having worked with top entertainment companies, including American Girl Dolls, Warner Bros., and AMC (The Walking Dead). Lauren completed her undergraduate studies at Carnegie Mellon University and her masters at the University of Pennsylvania.

sessions.title: Creating Augmented & Mixed Reality Applications for the Auto Industry

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: It's an extremely exciting time in automotive, with major advances underway in assisted driving, ride-sharing, electrification and more. And cars themselves are evolving beyond just transportation, with the passenger's digital experience becoming of equal importance to the vehicle's exterior design or mechanical performance. In this session – which showcases projects from Nissan, Honda, Mattel, and the LA Auto Show – learn how Unity's flexibility allows users to create powerful augmented (AR) and mixed reality (MR) applications for a wide variety of use cases, including enterprise tools that let global design teams collaborate in real-time, hot marketing apps that transform consumers' in-dealership experience, and AR/MR/VR apps for imagining the future of transportation.

speaker.title: CEO and Executive Creative Director
speaker.bio:
Jason is the CEO and Executive Creative Director of Trigger – The Mixed Reality Agency™, with offices in Los Angeles and Aarhus, Denmark. He has creatively led over 100,000 hours of development in mixed reality (MR), including as a Snapchat Lens Studio Partner and as a showcase developer for Vuforia (a leading AR platform) and Google.

Jason's recent high-profile work incorporates mixed reality in marketing (Star Wars: The Last Jedi), product development (Hot Wheels – Augmoto), location-based experiences (Fish Designer for LEGO House) and enterprise tools (AR Design Evaluation tool for Honda), all of which demonstrate the wide spectrum of use cases for mixed reality across all industries.

In 2015, Jason returned to his childhood home to speak at TEDx Hong Kong on "Computer Vision Bringing Toys to Life." Additionally, he has four assigned patents in AR/MR, with several more pending. He was also featured in Apple's first TV show: Planet of the Apps and won two LA Auto Show Design Challenges back-to-back with his partners at LEGO and the Honda Advanced Design.

speaker.title: Senior Director of Technology
speaker.bio: Danny is the Senior Director of Technology at Trigger – The Mixed Reality Agency™, where he leads projects for some of Trigger's biggest clients, including Mattel/Hot Wheels, Honda, the Star Wars franchise, LEGO and more. Danny is an integral part of the Trigger team as he is actively involved with all technological decisions, from ideation through to product delivery, and oversees all projects that the development team works on. His first project at Trigger was McDonald's GOL! for the 2014 FIFA World Cup; available in 119 countries, this was the most advanced AR mobile app at the time of its launch. Danny started his career at Google as a Developer Operations and at UCLA as Programmer-Analyst. With 12 years of tech and software engineering experience, he applies great knowledge of Unity and other aspects of software development to every project.

sessions.title: Democratize Machine Learning: ML-Agents Explained

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Recent advances in mathematics, computation, and data are radically redefining what is possible with machine learning (ML). These new techniques have made ML not only more tractable, but broadened the potential uses for it in game production and beyond!  In this session, we'll go over Unity ML-Agents, an open source toolkit that bridges the world of Unity and Machine Learning.  We'll go over how advances in AI, such as reinforcement and imitation learning, can open the door for new ways of game development.

speaker.title: Senior Machine Learning Engineer
speaker.bio: Arthur Juliani is a Machine Learning Engineer at Unity Technologies, and the lead developer of Unity ML-Agents. A researcher at the intersection of Cognitive Neuroscience and Deep Learning, Arthur is currently working toward a Ph.D. at the University of Oregon. An active blogger on topics such as Deep Learning, Reinforcement Learning, and Cognitive Science, his Medium blog has reached over 100,000 readers.  Arthur is also a contributor to well-known machine learning publications such as O'Reilly, and Hanbit Media.

sessions.title: Designing for Virality

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Whether paid or free, the competition for mobile users is heating up. The cost per install on the Tier 1 markets surpassed $3. At the same time, Google and Apple are changing recommendation algorithms that negatively impact organic in-store discovery. During this session, you'll learn how can you tap into your most valuable users and attract their friends. Discover the three levels or virality features you can implement, learn how much effort it will take, and find out what results you should expect and how to measure them. You'll also see examples from the most viral games and understand how shiny new Unity A/B testing tools and Tutorial Manager can help you.

text.name: TALK_TEXT2
text.value:
Game developers who want to learn how to add virality mechanics to their games, but do not know where to start and what results to expect.

The session will explain general concepts about viral mechanics, there will be no code heavy slides. Content is structured in a way to explain:

- For developers: key technical points (deep linking on Unity, A/B testing implementation notes)
- For game design and business: different viral mechanics and their metrics

text.name: TALK_TEXT3
text.value:
Developers will 
- Get understanding how much time it will take to build different virality features
- What technical aspects (e.g. deep linking) to focus on 
- Get a glimpse on how to use Unity A/B testing and Tutorial Manager to optimize virality features

Game designers will
- Learn on examples how to embed virality mechanics to the game to maximize social acquisition results

Business people will
- Learn about virality metrics 
- Set expectations about the results of different depth of viral features integrations

text.name: TALK_TEXT4
text.value:
Speaker notes:

Keynote, TEDx and serial technical conferences speaker. Favorite events I was speaking at:
- Game dev: Casual Connect Amsterdam, Game Developer Conference Ukraine
- Mobile development: DevTalks Romania (keynote), DevFest Ukraine (keynote), Droidcon Berlin, Droidcon Moscow

Full (almost) list of sessions: https://speakerhub.com/speaker/vitaliy-zasadnyy?b=s

As a side note, I'm leading the technical team for GetSocial SDK, the Unity Certified Asset.

__________________________________________


Session outline:

# Describe the problem
- Paid user acquisition is getting too expensive, it is hard to get high enough LTV to be profitable
- Organic UA is getting harder as well: Google Play changed recommendation algorithms that negatively affected organic in-store games discovery; Apple with a new featured apps design decreased amount of slots available

# Solution
- Utilize existing audience to grow. Virality features like referral campaigns, game design for social UA will decrease CPI. Also, data shows that socially acquired users retain 3x time longer.
- Virality metrics: k-factor, invites per mile, invites per user

# Three levels of virality features
- L1: add share button. Easy, but useless
- L2: incentivized sharing. Requires logic to handle reward on client + optionally backend to properly validate sharing the result. Number of users you can get.
- L3: integrate sharing to tutorial, quests, gameplay. Requires effort from developers + game designers. Can deliver recurring friend invites from users.

speaker.title: Head of Mobile
speaker.bio:
Vitaliy leads the mobile department at GetSocial -- the leading social layer provider for mobile games and apps.
For the last 7 years, he has launched mobile games and created SDKs with a total reach of over 250 million users. Vitaliy specializes in building and growing mobile products on Android and iOS. Recently his attention shifted to mobile user acquisition via various social mechanics. During his free time, he shares his experiences and knowledge with the community by giving talks at events like Casual Connect, DevTalks, and TEDx.

sessions.title: Designing XR Experiences with Speech & Natural Language Understanding in Unity

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value:
Designing complex interactions for experiences that target XR headsets can be challenging due to the limited input schemes. Advances in Machine Learning (ML) now allow developers to easily leverage Natural Language Understanding through reusable techniques. The combination of XR+AI is a powerful integration that opens new possibilities for both gaming, entertainment and enterprise scenarios.

This intermediate session is an exploration of how speech and language understanding can be used to augment Mixed Reality & VR experiences. We'll explore the use of speech recognition & Natural Language Understanding to build advanced voice commands, translate languages from within XR environments, and also look at the creation of intelligent conversation assistants to be used as interactive entities in Mixed Reality and VR apps & games. In a world where speech is the primary form of input, using Machine Learning to process language input and understand the user's intent is of paramount importance.

speaker.title: Senior Software Engineer
speaker.bio: Nick Landry (@ActiveNick) is a mobility pioneer and former entrepreneur specializing in solving technical problems via Mixed Reality, Conversational AI and the cloud. Nick works at Microsoft as a Senior Mixed Reality Software Engineer in the New York Metro area. On top of his career in IT consulting, software and services companies, Nick is also an indie game developer & designer, focusing on role-playing games, simulators, VR games & experiences, cloud gaming and more. GitHub: http://github.com/activenick

sessions.title: Developing Immersive Experiences with ARCore

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: In this intermediate-level session, you will learn about Google's recently launched AR platform, ARCore: How it works, the vast breadth of applications it enables, and how you can get started developing on ARCore.

speaker.title: Software Engineer
speaker.bio: Matthew works as a Software Engineer at Google leading the team that develops the ARCore for Unity SDK.

sessions.title: Developing Realistic Sensors for AV Simulations

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: This session will focus on sensor creation and explore the challenges around building simulated sensors that can be used for the development of autonomous vehicles, including the most common types and techniques and hear from partners that have been developing highly accurate sensor models on Unity.

sessions.title: Digital Omotenashi: Bringing the Lexus LC 500 to Life via the Magic of Real-Time

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Discover how the convergence of marketing and technology is changing the world of automotive marketing and customer experience through the lens of the Lexus LC 500's journey to market. As trends such as the proliferation of touch, omni-channel personalization, cloud services, new devices and media demand, and machine learning/AI take hold and evolve, explore how new solutions from Unity can benefit wide-ranging applications, including working with design data, dynamic use cases, design and engineering visualization, and marketing and advertising.

speaker.title: Management Director, Digital
speaker.bio:
Digital practitioner, basset hound rescuer, husband, amateur wine snob, Seattle-native, and USC Trojan.

By day, Joe is head of digital at Team One (Saatchi & Saatchi/Publicis Groupe's premium, luxury, and aspirational brand agency), where he leads a multi-disciplinary team of strategists, creatives, and technologists, and works with clients like Lexus, the Ritz-Carlton, and Indian Motorcycle. By night, Joe is head of TiltShift, Publicis Groupe's VR/immersive reality consultancy and production studio.
 
Before joining Team One, Joe opened and led the Razorfish Los Angeles office, where he managed the Honda and Acura digital agency of record account. He led the T-Mobile digital account during its industry-revolutionizing "Un-carrier" brand relaunch, and worked with companies like Visa, Amazon, and Qualcomm.
 
Joe is recognized for implementing transformative ideas in complex organizations, including a global enterprise technology strategy he led for Procter & Gamble, which Apple featured in a case study in their marketing.
 
In addition to helping some of the world's leading brands develop and implement their digital strategies, Joe has a passion for the arts. He founded the world's largest non-profit educational jazz festival in honor of his father, Frank. And during his time at Seattle-based digital agency POP, his team developed and managed the websites, mobile apps, e-commerce, and email programs for organizations like Carnegie Hall, the Sydney Opera House, the Royal Opera House, and the Metropolitan Opera. Joe also led the development of one of the first mobile ticketing platforms, a highly-scalable ticket engine, and in partnership with his long-time hero Frank Gehry, he led the design of digital installations for New York City's new Signature Theatre.

Don't tell anyone, but before working for agencies, Joe sang backup vocals for artists like the Steve Miller Band, Bonnie Raitt, and Kurt Elling.

sessions.title: Directing a VR Experience with Baobab

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: To be revealed

sessions.title: ECS: Building a Living, Breathing World on a Shoestring Budget

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: In this session, you will be introduced to he the editing tools developed for streaming worlds and how we utilized nested prefabs and variants to manage permutations and ease content productions. In addition, you will learn about the optimizations made to render the scene.

speaker.title: Technical Art Director
speaker.bio: Martin has been making game art for two decades with a start in modding the first Quake engine games. Today his experience in game production spans 4 console generations. Originally starting in environment art, he expanded into technical art and tool design. Martin previously lead the environment art team at IO Interactive (SQEX) on the Hitman series where he also collaborated on tools and rendering development. Since 2016, he has worked as Technical Art Director on Sample Games at Unity Technologies.

sessions.title: ECS: Changing Transforms? We're on It!

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: The Transform component is a core part of Unity used by almost all other systems. In this session, you learn how and why it has changed for ECS and what that means for you as a user..

speaker.title: Programmer
speaker.bio: Jens started by writing BASIC programs with pen and paper. Eventually, his parents realized that this wasn't a passing fad and bought him his first computer. He's called himself a programmer ever since. He started at IO Interactive in 2000 and has worked on games ranging from indie-size to AAA blockbusters. He has mainly worked with engine tech and tools and believes strongly in engine development being driven by the needs of the games that are developed with it. Jens started at Unity in 2016 where he has mainly worked on changes to the Transform component and the systems that use it.

sessions.title: ECS: Deep Dive into the Burst Compiler

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Come to this talk to get a behind-the-scenes peek at the Burst Compiler. Learn about the challenges of generating better native code from a subset of IL/.NET called High Performance C#. Find out how Burst is being developed and tested, what kind of optimizations it can bring, and how to take advantage of it in your project by using a data-oriented programming approach. You'll also get insight into what we are doing into to improve it in the future.

speaker.title: Software Engineer
speaker.bio: Alexandre joined Unity in 2016 as a Software Engineer leading the development of a new compiler technology from C# to native code. Prior to this, he spent five years involved in the architecture and development of an innovative game engine written entirely in C#. He is also an Open-Source developer and has been contributing to several OSS projects, including SharpDX and Markdig. He has been recognized as a Microsoft MVP since 2014 in Visual Studio and Development Technologies. Alexandre loves to work on complex systems, improving their designs and empowering users.

sessions.title: ECS: Graph Driven Audio in an ECS World

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Come learn about a new C# job-based audio rendering engine, which has been developed for Unity. You'll get an introduction to this low-level audio renderer and an understanding of the ECS technology that brings large-scale audio to the demo.

speaker.title: TBC
speaker.bio: Wayne has enjoyed working on a wide range of exciting and innovative features at Unity since 2012.Throughout his career, he's developed a strong interest in observing users' workflows and feature needs and abstracting and developing them into a cohesive, forward-thinking technology and tooling offering. In this capacity, he is currently serving as the tech lead on a number of core tech and feature projects within Unity.In his spare time, he enjoys cave diving and bringing technology to the world of this hobby, particularly in developing unique vision-based mapping and 3D reconstruction solutions.

sessions.title: ECS: LOD and Culling Systems That Scale

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Come see how we used Capsicum to display a large environment in the Unite LA streaming demo.

speaker.title: Principal Engineer
speaker.bio: Mike Acton has worked on game engines for over 20 years, including a period  of over 10 years as the Engine Director of Insomniac Games. He has learned hard lessons about what it takes to produce some of the highest quality work in the space and what is needed to meet those requirements. Mike is at Unity to make that possible for more people by helping to democratize data-oriented programming so that teams everywhere can achieve things only previously possible by a few dedicated groups. he strongly believes in giving back to our community. Mike edits in vi and prefers spaces to tabs.

sessions.title: ECS: Spline-Based AI Agents

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: In this session, we'll look at the traffic simulation in the demo examining the compute kernels and the code that Burst produces for them. We will also cover the spline-based AI agents and how they were developed with the ECS.

speaker.title: Software Engineer
speaker.bio:
Lee has worked as a programmer, at various levels and companies within the games industry for nearly 20 years. He started out making Gameboy Colour games, and finished off making games for PS4/Xbox One/PC before joining Unity Technologies in December 2017. He now spends his time working on the Burst compiler, and helping out wherever he can.

Lee is probably best known to the wider world by his various pseudonyms, none of which he will reveal here. His free time is spent resurrecting/reverse engineering old hardware, pulling at threads, and generally have a nice time playing board games.

speaker.title: Principal Engineer
speaker.bio: Andreas has worked on blockbuster games at DICE and Insomniac Games. He's credited on titles like Battlefield 2 and 3, as well as Ratchet and Clank PS4 and Sunset Overdrive. His career has mostly been focused on engine development, optimization and team leadership. At DICE, he was a part of the Frostbite engine team, working on the technology that powers EA's internal engine. At Insomniac, Andreas served as a lead engine programmer and gameplay director. At Unity, Andreas works on the future direction on the Unity engine, which aims to democratize Data-Oriented Design.

sessions.title: ECS: Streaming and Serialization

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: In this in-depth talk we'll cover entity serialization to and from disk, how we built seamless play mode streaming and efficient editor workflow, and what a separate ECS world can do for you.

speaker.title: Software Engineer
speaker.bio:
Simon has been working in the games industry since the original PlayStation time where 1 MB of memory was a lot. Through the years he maintained his keen interest in understanding the underlying hardware and how to optimize for it. This was instrumental in the development of the Glacier 2 engine that powered Hitman and Deus Ex games. 

Simon joined Unity in 2015 to help modularize and modernize the engine. For the last year he has helped develop the ECS system.

speaker.title: Developer
speaker.bio: Fabrice has been a programmer in the games industry since 2003 working for small studios on a wide range of games for PC, mobile and consoles. Besides writing code, he enjoys explaining it, so it's no surprise that he has also worked as a teacher for several years. He has a passion for the history of computing, most particularly everything that predates the microcomputer revolution. When not in front of a keyboard or card punch, Fabrice can be found reading a book or hiking.

sessions.title: ECS: Using the Entity Debugger

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Come get an introduction to the functions of the Entity Debugger and hear a discussion of its place in future versions of Unity.

speaker.title: Editor Developer
speaker.bio: Daniel is a long-time Unity user and tools programmer with a passion for user-interface design. He enjoys reducing the number of steps and amount of time it takes users to get their work done.Daniel got his start in the games industry  in Canada making hidden object games and eventually supporting a small team making more and more complex games. He moved to Copenhagen in 2015 to join the Editor team at Unity where he works on tools used by a number of people that is several orders of magnitude larger.

sessions.title: ECS: Welcome and General Overview

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Joachim Ante will open the ECS track by presenting what he and his team have been working on for the last 6 months.

speaker.title: CTO
speaker.bio: As Unity's Chief Technology Officer and co-founder, Joachim Ante has brought pro-level game tools to the masses and is playing a significant role in the renaissance of independent games. Joachim initially began writing the core of Unity as a teenager, and today, the engine is used by more than 4.5 million registered developers.

sessions.title: Enhancing GPU Performance with Texture Streaming

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: This talk will cover the Unity 2018.2 feature Mip Map Streaming. Learn how to enhance your GPU performance using Mip Maps and reduce GPU texture memory through streaming, loading Mip Maps into memory only when needed.

speaker.title: Technical Evangelist
speaker.bio: As a Technical Evangelist at Unity Technologies, Liz Mercuri engages regularly with the game development community aiming to instill confidence and promote diversity in the next generation of game development talent. Whether mentoring at student game jams, delivering talks and demos on the latest Unity features or promoting computer games as a viable career option, Liz seizes every opportunity to empower developers.

sessions.title: Fast Worldbuilding with Unity's Updated Terrain System & ProBuilder

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: This beginner session will show you how to quickly create and iterate on playable levels using ProBuilder and the recently updated Terrain system.

speaker.title: Unity Evangelist
speaker.bio: Dan is an AR/VR evangelist at Unity. He has worked in game development for several years as a developer, with a recent focus in VR. He's excited to help others explore the forefront of new and emergent technologies, and the many unique opportunities they present.

speaker.title: Evangelist
speaker.bio: Regularly engaging with the game development community, Liz has the fortunate opportunity to encourage and empower the next generation of game development talent. Whether she is mentoring at student game jams, delivering talks on the latest Unity features or getting involved in local initiatives to promote computer games as a viable career option, she realizes the importance of empowering developers, instilling confidence and promoting diversity in the game development community.

sessions.title: From 0 to 90: Achieving Peak Performance in Multiplatform VR Development

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value:
Great VR can transform our perception of reality, but in order to achieve this, it's critical that you develop an experience that runs at an optimized framerate for your target platform.

In this intermediate-level session, Devin Reimer (Chief Executive Owl) and Andrew Eiche (Chief Technology Owl), will share the best practices and optimization techniques used to develop Owlchemy Labs' award-winning multi-platform games.

You'll learn techniques for optimizing Unity projects to meet the often extreme performance requirements of VR, including detailed use of profiling, understanding batching, writing performant scripts, object hierarchies, managing and debugging the Unity physics system, offloading processing to Unity Jobs, and writing efficient shaders.

speaker.title: CEO
speaker.bio: Devin Reimer is CEO (Chief Executive Owl) of game studio, Owlchemy Labs, creators of the multi-platform VR title 'Job Simulator,' 'Rick and Morty: Virtual Rick-ality,' and the upcoming 'Vacation Simulator.' With many years of Unity and game-development experience, Devin has led the creation of multiple VR launch titles on the HTC Vive, Oculus Touch, and PlayStation VR, maintaining Owlchemy's reputation for bringing award-winning content to new platforms.

speaker.title: CTO
speaker.bio: Andrew Eiche is CTO (Chief Technology Owl) and Cable Wrangler of game studio, Owlchemy Labs, creators of the multi-platform VR titles 'Job Simulator,' 'Rick and Morty: Virtual Rick-ality,' and the upcoming 'Vacation Simulator.' Throughout his career, he has developed games for indies, board-game companies, commercial industry and government agencies. He used to wear a suit and tie to work. He also made an app for the IRS. Things are better now.

sessions.title: From Design to Dealer - VR/AR Software Solutions for Getting to "Yes"

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: REWIND and its new global technology partners will be revealing their live meet and review platform in development, which promises to revolutionize the automotive industry's design process with rapid stakeholder and consumer feedback. The software will make the creation of a car faster, from early design steps to final focus group testing. The VR/AR platform will also allow for easy collaborative input from internal stakeholders to consumers to ensure the grand vision can actually be experienced through immersive technology before anything is built. Join REWIND and executive guests - leading hardware and OEM partners -  for a live demo and special announcement.

speaker.title: CEO & Founder
speaker.bio:
Sol is the driving force behind REWIND's exponential growth and award-winning projects, including the multi-award-winning BBC Home: A VR Spacewalk, and Emmy-nominated Silicon Valley: Inside the Hacker Hostel for HBO.

Sol's leadership of REWIND and his respected position within the industry sees him regularly speaking at international events, quoted in the media, and appearing on TV. He is also Chairman of Immerse UK, the first nation-wide network for immersive companies and Chairman of BAFTA's Immersive Entertainment Advisory Group. 

Before founding REWIND, Sol was one of the youngest Senior Lecturers in the UK, writing four new degrees, two masters and supervising PHDs during his tenure.

speaker.title: GM
speaker.bio:
Rick Davis has worked in gaming and tech for 13 years in both San Francisco and Los Angeles. Most recently he created and evangelized the Autodesk LIVE brand, a long-term vision, and suite of products that brought real-time environments and VR to the design world for the global software company.  

Rick joined immersive content studio, REWIND, to expand the company's vision as an AR and VR innovator, creating world-class immersive experiences and software for brands, agencies, and studios.  Rick is also key to positioning REWIND as a value-driven technical solutions provider, focusing on building scalable software and owned IP.

sessions.title: From Interactive to Automatic CAD Data Prep

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: PiXYZ CAD data-prep experts will show you how to use PiXYZ products to convert, optimize and conform 3D models coming from the CAD industrial world to Unity, taking into consideration the challenges and effort behind each part of the CAD asset transformation pipeline for XR applications. Along the way, they will cover everything from simple use cases to extensive automatic CAD data-prep usage.

speaker.title: Head of UX & Brand Development
speaker.bio: Geoffrey is Head of UX & Brand Development at PiXYZ Software, whose products help industrial companies and agencies reuse CAD data for any visualization scenario, saving time, effort and maximizing performance. Geoffrey has expertise in CAD/VR/AR experiences that are at the crossroads of R&D, UX, marketing and sales. Prior to PiXYZ Software, he spent 10 years at Dassault Systèmes, leading various VR/AR, R&D, marketing, and product strategy activities.

speaker.title: Product Manager & Professional Services Manager
speaker.bio: Axel is a Product Manager and Professional Services Manager at PiXYZ Software. The company provides a portfolio of products dedicated to CAD data preparation and optimization, and CAD review. He has eight years of experience in project management and has a strong background in 3D market/software.

sessions.title: Get off to a Great Start with Handheld AR

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Are you an aspiring handheld AR app developer but not quite sure where to begin? In this beginner session, Unity XR evangelist, Dan Miller, will show you how to use our new handheld AR template and multiplatform AR SDK to build an app across ARCore and ARKit devices. You'll also get best practices and tips that will boost your confidence so you can start creating handheld AR apps on your own.

speaker.title: XR Evangelist
speaker.bio: Dan is an XR evangelist at Unity, where he works closely with new and emergent technologies. As an evangelist, he develops and delivers content to a wide audience mainly in the Americas region. Before joining Unity, he worked on multiple VR games and applications, including Cyberpong, which has been featured in arcades around the world. Dan is excited to continue helping the community create unique, compelling experiences in the Virtual and Augmented Reality space.

sessions.title: Get Up to Speed on Unity for Small Things

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Come to this session to learn how the Unity for Small Things initiative will enable you to deliver game content to players instantly with no install. You'll learn how editor workflows and an ECS-based modular runtime will enable you to produce projects with amazingly fast load times and very small transport sizes.  The initial release has been designed to deploy content via web technologies on mobile; An ideal solution for powering playable ads or games in social and messaging apps.  You'll leave with an overview of the project, what it can do today, and where development is heading next, including more details on the open beta.

speaker.title: Sr. Technical Product Manager
speaker.bio: Martin is the Senior Technical Product Manager responsible for all platforms at Unity.  He is heavily involved in the Unity for Small Things initiative.  Before joining Unity, Martin was the main product manager for Mozilla's web engine, Gecko, where he helped drive standards such as WebGL, WebVR, and WebAssembly.  Martin's early career was as a developer working on titles focused on the web, such as Habbo Hotel and the Emmy Winning, "ReGenesis ARG."

sessions.title: Getting Started with Lightweight Render Pipeline (LWRP) for Mobile

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: In this intermediate-level session, Unity Evangelist Josh Naylor will give you a quick overview of the three available render pipelines in Unity 2018 and their major features and benefits for mobile apps. At the end of the presentation, attendees will have a good understanding of how to select the most suitable pipeline for their own projects or when to write their own.

speaker.title: Evangelism Lead EMEA
speaker.bio: Leading the Evangelism team in EMEA, Josh travels the world meeting the amazing Unity community. Whether at conferences, expos, user groups or game jams, Josh loves to demo new and existing Unity features, and to "spread the love" among this amazingly creative industry.

sessions.title: Getting Started with Pixel Perfect

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Pixel Perfect is a new package in Preview that easily lets you create precise and clean pixel-art games in Unity. In this short introduction, Unity Evangelist Josh Naylor will walk you through this new feature and leave you with some great tips & tricks to use in your retro or 2D pixelated game.

speaker.title: Evangelism Lead EMEA
speaker.bio: Leading the Evangelism team in EMEA, Josh travels the world meeting the amazing Unity community. Whether at conferences, expos, user groups or game jams, Josh loves to demo new and existing Unity features, and to "spread the love" among this amazingly creative industry.

sessions.title: Getting Started with the Lightweight Render Pipeline

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Andy will present a high-level overview of the technology behind the new Scriptable Render Pipeline (SRP) and demonstrate how to set up the Lightweight Scriptable Render Pipeline (LWRP) in the Editor. You will learn about the performance advantages that SRP can bring to projects targeting mobile platforms, VR and games with limited real-time lighting needs. You will also find out how the rendering features differ from the built-in renderer in a way that improves performance in limited platforms. Finally, you will learn how to get started using SRP for your project.

speaker.title: Unity Evangelist
speaker.bio: Andy Touch is a content evangelist at Unity. He focuses on creating example projects to demonstrate upcoming features and teaching the Unity community how they can take their games to the next level.

speaker.title: Graphics Product Manager
speaker.bio: Arisa Scott is Unity’s graphics product manager. She has a bachelors is in fine arts from Digipen, where she found a passion for game art pipelines. Before Unity, Arisa worked at several technology and game companies. Right before Unity Arisa was at Artifact Technologies, working on location based apps/games, and getting to hang out at comic cons to pitch games. Prior to that Arisa co-founded a game company, as the art director on a 2D CCG/tower defense game.

sessions.title: Go Binary Or Go Home: How to Speed up Data Loading on Mobile!

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: JSON is a great data format, but not the best for large data sets at loadtime/runtime.  In this session, you'll learn about some alternatives and how they can speed up loading/parsing and save memory too!  You'll also wee sample benchmarks running on mobiles devices and learn the methods and techniques for optimizing your data for the best possible performance.

text.name: TALK_TEXT2
text.value: Development

text.name: TALK_TEXT3
text.value: Audience will have an understanding of the various technologies for loading large data sets (json, custom binary, etc) and will get full source access to a sample app to run on mobile devices that will report various benchmarks.

speaker.title: Director, Software Engineering
speaker.bio: Martin Robaszewski has worked on desktop, console and mobile games for companies such as Ubisoft, Atari, Epic Games and even the US Army. He is currently leading the client engineering team on Design Home for Glu Mobile's Crowdstar studio.

sessions.title: Graphics: to be revealed
How to Build an Audience with WebGL

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Marketing your game early and often is crucial to success. One innovative strategy is to share WebGL builds during development to create a following. This talk will explain some of the nuts and bolts of deploying your game to the web like a pro, and how to put live browser builds in some unconventional places like Kickstarter, Patreon, Medium and Gamasutra.
