You'll also learn how to solve some common technical challenges and get development flow tips for how to get the most out of WebGL.

text.name: TALK_TEXT2
text.value: The talk is intended for a wide audience. There will be some technical aspects, but there will also be a discussion of how to market your game on the web and where to post it to get noticed.

text.name: TALK_TEXT3
text.value: Folks will learn about how to deploy games to various services on the web, common gotcha's and settings to create a professional looking web builds, WebGL development flow tips, and how to share web builds in places like Kickstarter, Patreon, and Medium, the blogging platform.

text.name: TALK_TEXT4
text.value:
I've had about a dozen speaking engagements at places like ForwardJS, HTML5 Developers Conference, Unity Unite, and Google. I also teach an online courses on Udemy.

This year's talk will be about 90% fresh content, with a little recap / primer at the beginning.

I did a talk last year about WebGL that was rated pretty highly by the audience (feedback attached for your convenience). 

Hope I get to do a session again this year!

speaker.title: Founder
speaker.bio: Rocco Balsamo is the Founder of SIMMER.io, the simplest place for developers to share WebGL games. A lifelong games enthusiast, he published his first game at the age of 14, garnering 40,000+ downloads on AOL's game channel. He has worked on 15+ commercial projects, including Rock Band 3, The Sims 2, and Death Jr (a game about the son of the grim reaper). Since 2010, he has shifted his focus to web development working on HTML5 games and products like Gliffy, a graphical diagram editor for the web. He's mega-enthusiastic about technologies like WebGL and WebAssembly, and thinks the web will become the preferred delivery platform for games by 2025. Rocco lives with his wife and son in San Francisco.

sessions.title: How You Can Develop AI with the  IBM Watson SDK for Unity

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Continuing advances in APIs and SDKs are democratizing AI, enabling anyone to be an AI developer, including you!  But if you're not sure where to start, this session is for you. Learn how to leverage the IBM Watson SDK for Unity to create dynamic and unique experiences even if you're not an AI developer. At the end of this intro session, you'll have useful code snippets to get you up and running quickly on your own projects. Some experience scripting in Unity may help, but isn't required for this session.

speaker.title: Developer Advocate
speaker.bio: Amara Keller is a Developer Advocate with IBM. Before her step into developer relations, she was an enterprise web application developer focusing on line-of-business applications and assisting developers across various teams on implementing proprietary and open source solutions. She's passionate about UX, technical communities (both online and offline) and excited to see where advances in AI take us. In her spare time, Amara experiments in the kitchen and plays console video games.

sessions.title: Improving Your Pathfinding with the Navmesh API

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Learn to use the low-level NavMesh query API to achieve better control over NPC navigation. Discover new possibilities for doing pathfinding at various priority levels and also for adjusting an agent's path according to different needs. You'll also hear how we plan to extend this API in the near future.

speaker.title: Software Developer
speaker.bio: Ever since he joined a game studio 10 years ago, Adrian has sought to write gameplay logic that would transform the artificial into a form that humans could perceive as natural, comfortable and fun. That included programming character behaviors for Assassin's Creed Multiplayer games, early prototypes for the control of the main hero in Mafia III, and even driving cars through the deserted towns of DayZ together with an online crew of other potentially friendly survivors. Today Adrian's mission in Unity is to provide game developers with easy access to fast and reliable algorithms for navigation and pathfinding. These two can really help bring a game world to life.

sessions.title: Inside the Magic at Magic Leap

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: What is spatial computing and is it the future of augmented reality? Find out more by attending this in-depth session led by Brian Schwab of Magic Leap. You'll hear about the design paradigm shift and a new set of tools you can use to explore and design exciting experiences around characters and environments.

speaker.title: Director of Interaction Lab
speaker.bio: After spending more than 20 years as a gameplay and AI programmer in the game industry, Brian Schwab joined a little Florida company who's mission was not so little: to fundamentally change how humans use and interact with their computers. So, while in his past he shipped everything from a simple Sega Genesis jrpg to the international blockbuster Hearthstone at Blizzard, he now runs the Interaction Lab, a systems research group within Magic Leap. In addition to using crazy new hardware to explore interactions from low level to hugely complex, his team also helps bring compelling experience to the forefront of the Magic Leap engineering efforts. Throughout this, his mission has never changed: to find fun, interactive experiences and share them with the world.

sessions.title: Introducing the FPS.Sample and Its HD Graphics

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Come learn about a new Unity sample game that you will be able to download for learning, inspiration, or to use as you please in your own creations. The First Person Shooter Sample is a project designed to show product-grade implementations of Unity features, including graphics and networking, in a real-time multiplayer context. In this session, Martin will introduce the FPS.Sample Game and the High-Definition Render Pipeline (HDRP) used in the project.

speaker.title: Technical Art Director, Sample Games
speaker.bio: Martin has been making art for games for two decades. His first steps into game art were taken when he modded the first Quake engine games, and today his experience in game production spans four console generations. Starting in environment art, Martin has expanded into technical art and tool design. He previously lead the environment art team at Io Interactive (SQEX) on the Hitman series where he also collaborated on tools and rendering development. Since 2016, he has worked as Technical Art Director on the Sample Games team at Unity Technologies.

sessions.title: Introducing the FPS.Sample – Networking

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Come learn about a new Unity sample game that you will be able to download and use for learning, inspiration, or even to use as you please for your own creations. You'll get introduced to this First-Person Shooter project, which was created in-house at Unity,  You'll learn how it was designed to show product-grade implementations of Unity features, including graphics and networking, in a real-time multiplayer context, and you'll see how the netcode of a fast-paced multiplayer shooter like the fps.sample works.

sessions.title: Introducing the New Prefab Workflow

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Want a great introduction about prefabs in Unity 2018? Attend this session! In just 25 minutes, seasoned game developer and technical evangelist Ciro Continisio will explain all the major aspects of our new Prefab workflow (e.g., Nesting, Variants, Prefab Isolation Edit mode). He'll also tell you about the new UI/UX elements and the reasoning behind them.

speaker.title: Technical Evangelist
speaker.bio: Ciro joined Unity as Technical Evangelist for the EMEA region after years of developing games at his own company. He travels from conference to conference, spreading the word about Unity. His role involves showcasing new features and advocating good development practices, but you'll also hear a lot about game design along the way. Combined with his passion for teaching and education, his soft spot for design makes game jams his natural habitat.

sessions.title: Intuitive 3D Content Creation for Automotive VR

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: See how creating high-quality NURBS surfaces can be as natural and intuitive as sculpting in the real world. Built with Unity, Gravity Sketch is a multi-platform 3D-creation tool that enables you to immerse yourself in your design, eliminating barriers between your inspiration and 3D modeling. At this session, learn about the benefits of directly creating models in VR and meet the innovators who are bringing this new technology to the market.

speaker.title: Senior Automotive Designer, 3D Modeling and Visualization
speaker.bio:
James Robbins is a senior designer with the Digital Modeling and Visualization group at Honda R&D, Inc. He primarily works with Alias and Modo, but has now jumped head first into VR sketching, sculpting and modeling. James has always been interested in new design techniques and processes that can help the creative workflow.

James is a graduate of the Industrial Design: Transportation track from the University of Cincinnati. He's worked with many talented and inspiring design, marketing and engineering teams across many design fields to develop and implement products from concept through production.

sessions.title: Leverage MixPlay Interactivity to Grow Your Audience on Mixer

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: On Mixer, viewers play along with streamers via interactive elements created with the MixPlay development tool. This introduces a new paradigm for online multiplayer experiences. In this intermediate session, you'll learn how to quickly integrate MixPlay elements with your Unity game to create compelling content that streamers and viewers love. You'll leave with an understanding of how to successfully integrate MixPlay, and get a free promotion on Mixer.

speaker.title: Program Manager
speaker.bio: A computer engineer by trade, Mike Blouin is currently a program manager at Xbox, where he works on online competitive experiences.

sessions.title: Look Ma, No Jutter! Optimizing Performance Across Oculus Mobile

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: The introduction of mobile AR means the arrival of more accessible devices, and for developers, a broader range of consumers to target. The good news is that you're "already ready." A stable of universal techniques and best practices can help reduce draw calls and maximize performance without sacrificing fidelity across Gear VR, Oculus Go, and Project Santa Cruz. We'll start with an overview of the devices and basic considerations, and go step by step through the process of reviewing and optimizing textures, scene geometry, and lighting. Attendees interested in Project Santa Cruz will also benefit from an introduction to Unity's profiling workflow.

speaker.title: Developer Relations Engineer
speaker.bio: At Oculus, Gabor Szauer supports developers targeting mobile platforms like Gear VR, Oculus Go and the prototype Project Santa Cruz. In his spare time, he makes video games and has written a few books about game development.

sessions.title: Lotte Makes Stuff: ECS for Small Platformers

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: LotteMakesStuff (https://lottemakesstuff.pink/i) is the home for all the Unity things that Lotte makes with Unity like tutorials, tools and feature deep-dives. In this session, you can join Lotte as she explores the possibilities of the Entity Component System (ECS). The ECS opens the doors for making super cool, giant scale simulations, but how do you actually make a game with it? In this session, you can learn how to build a simple, yet complete 2D platformer using ECS by watching Lotte do what she loves to do most of all: Make things.

speaker.title: Influencer
speaker.bio: Lotte May is better known by her Twitter handle: Lotte makes stuff. And boy does she ever -- make stuff, that is. Lots of stuff! Tweets, photos of yummy food, videos of foxes and hamsters, but mostly video game stuff. She's been working as a game dev since 2009 and building stuff with Unity pretty much every day since version 3.0 came out in 2010. Lotte has been a programmer on a whole bunch of amazing indie games. If you've ever battled against a virus in an online Plague Inc. multiplayer match or browsed through abilities in The Swindle's in-game perk system, you've been playing with code that Lotte touched.

sessions.title: Making Games Universal: How to Develop for Big Brands with Small Studios

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: In this high-level session, learn how developers from around the world came together to build games for their favorite Universal brands. Various winning developers from the Universal GameDev Challenge will share their stories of success, and how to strike the balance between artistic creation and commercial collaboration.

speaker.title: Partner Marketing Manager
speaker.bio: In her role on the Unity team, Lydia administered Unity's largest contest to date, bringing together major partners from across the industry to help guide, mentor, and enable the success of a worldwide team of finalists to make their vision come to life.

sessions.title: Making Your CAD Data Shine!

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: A look at Unity's CAD importing capabilities with the PiXYZ's plugin and Unity's new Automotive Material Library.

speaker.title: Evangelist  (VR/AR)
speaker.bio: Mark Schoennagel is a Unity Evangelist with a strong technical background in 3D Animation for both film and video games. For nearly 20 years, he was the lead evangelist for Softimage 3D, enjoying a front-row seat during the renaissance of the 3D industry. From witnessing the humble beginnings of the first ray-traced animations all the way through to today's blockbuster AAA game titles, he's seen it all. When not pushing the limits of 3D, Mark enjoys Formula 1, photography and VR… which of course is just more 3D.

sessions.title: Mobile AR and the Future of Authoring - Unity Labs

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: At this intermediate-level session, you'll meet the Unity Labs Authoring Tools Group, whose motto is "Reality is our build target," and whose goal is to enable developers to create apps that live in and react to the real world. They'll explain their approach to mixed reality (MR) development, talk about how the Project MARS Unity extension handles various data and simulations in the Editor, and also how they integrate with technology providers. Finally, you'll learn how the team is defining and handling privacy and permissions for spatial computing.

speaker.title: Advanced UX on the Labs Team at Unity
speaker.bio: Charles leads Advanced UX on the Unity Labs team. He has designed both 2D and 3D authoring systems over the past two decades, working for companies like Softimage, Microsoft, Avid, Sony, and Apple, before joining Unity in 2017. Working with teams of designers and engineers, his goal is to enable digital artists to achieve their creative vision with tools that are powerful, efficient, elegant and delightful to use.

speaker.title: Director of XR Research
speaker.bio: Timoni leads design on Unity's Labs team, focusing on the future of game development and creation tools in VR. Labs' first project, EditorVR, was released in December 2016. Before Unity, Timoni was SVP of Design at Alphaworks, and co-founder and creative director of Department of Design. She's also a mentor at the Upload Collective, advising new VR startups in the Bay Area.

speaker.title: Senior Software Engineer
speaker.bio: Andrew Maneri has dedicated his life to programming, designing, and creating. He has worked and produced in nearly every gaming and XR vertical. His passions are VR/AR, game development, graphics programming, technical art, automation, and animation. Andrew works with Unity Labs, a team of cross-disciplinary artists and engineers exploring new interfaces for human-computer interaction. His unique background and skill set have led to unorthodox and mind-bending experiments in the digital space.

speaker.title: Software Engineer
speaker.bio: Kyle is a software engineer at Unity Labs working on authoring tools and prototypes, including MARS and EditorXR. At USC, he studied computer science for video games and interned at the Jet Propulsion Lab on AR applications. Kyle's goal is to make new technology more accessible for all creators and to explore the frontiers of spatial computing and interactive entertainment.

sessions.title: NASA AR Procedure Assistance for Space Applications

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: NASA JPL has an ongoing effort to utilize AR for enhancing procedure execution for space applications. In this session, Benjamin will present their latest AR procedure execution system running inside ProtoSpace, their immersive CAD visualization tool built with Unity and HoloLens. He'll also showcase real-world examples as well as discuss lessons learned and future applications.

speaker.title: Immersive User Interface Developer
speaker.bio: Benjamin is a mixed-reality researcher and developer focused on applying MR technologies to enhance mission planning and execution systems in the OpsLab at the NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL). He currently works on ProtoSpace, a collaborative, immersive CAD visualization tool used in a variety of NASA projects. Before working at JPL, Benjamin researched MR remote collaboration in the Four Eyes Lab at the University of California, Santa Barbara, where he received his Ph.D. in Computer Science.

sessions.title: New 2D World-Building, Animation & Graphics Features in Unity

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Many powerful new features are about to be released for building 2D worlds, animating 2D characters and optimizing your graphics in 2D. This intermediate-level session will explore organic world-building with Sprite Shape as well as improvements to Tilemap for grid-based layouts. We will discuss and demo Phase 2 of our 2D Sprite Rigging tools for 2D animation and enhancements to 2D graphics, including the Pixel Perfect Camera. We will also be providing a sneak peek into the future of 2D at Unity.

speaker.title: Technical Product Manager, 2D
speaker.bio: Rustum (Rus) is a Product Manager for 2D in R&D at Unity. He has been making games for more than 10 years and developing in Unity almost as long. Rus owns Craft Colony, a game production and consulting company, is a games technology generalist, and takes a holistic approach to game development. He is an MSC Malaysia Intellectual Property Creators Challenge (IPCC) winner. In 2012, he released Penyu the Turtle, a top‐down shooter for iOS. He also launched and managed Malaysia's first online portal for game assets. Previously, he was Technical Art Director at Big Bad Robots and Senior 3D Artist at GameBrains.

speaker.title: Technical Evangelist Intern (EMEA)
speaker.bio: Alessia is a Technical Evangelist at Unity and an AI enthusiast. She started developing small games at game jams and hackathons, and she joined Unity to develop and demonstrate feature projects and share tips about Unity at conferences and meet-ups around the world. As a gamer, she is passionate about immersive story-based adventures and anything experimental.

sessions.title: New Addressable Asset System for Speed and Performance

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: The new Addressable Asset system makes it much easier to manage your game assets and project workflow, and it gives you better options to optimize performance. In this advanced session, learn how the new system works and explore some common and challenging use cases.

speaker.title: Lead Software Developer
speaker.bio: Stephen is the Development Lead at Unity Austin, where he oversees the evolution of the Unity build pipeline, including Addressables, Asset Bundles and the Unity Cloud Build service. Prior to joining Unity, Stephen spent over 15 years as a professional game developer in a variety of roles, including level design, programming, and production. He has been on the ground floor of small indie studios, and also led large game projects with multi-million-dollar budgets and teams of 100+ individuals, managing communications with publishing partners, outsourcing studios, and sub-contracted developers. His credits include games in the Half-Life, Halo, Brothers in Arms, Borderlands, and Call of Duty series.

speaker.title: Senior Software Engineer
speaker.bio: Bill is a member of Unity Austin's Build Pipeline and Asset Bundle team. He is the technical lead on the new Addressable Assets project and is focused on improving asset management workflows. Prior to joining Unity, Bill was a software developer for over 10 years. Half that time he spent as a game and tools programmer in the brick-and-mortar casino games industry. He is credited with over a dozen casino games as well as several artist- and programmer-centric tools.

sessions.title: New Tools for Graphic Realism in Automotive

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: In this intermediate-level session, Adam Myhill, Unity's Head of Cinematics, will show you how you can achieve high-end graphics in Unity for automotive applications. You'll learn how Unity's High-Definition Render Pipeline (HDRP), Cinemachine, Timeline, and the Post-Processing Stack can be used to produce stunning visuals with maximum fidelity for real-world materials. This session will also include a comprehensive breakdown of layout, rendering and 4K resolution, and how together they can help you level-up your project for trailers or cinematic applications.

speaker.title: Head of Cinematics
speaker.bio: Adam has spent almost two decades in the video game and film worlds, working as a Director of Photography and CG supervisor at EA, Pandemic and Blackbird Interactive across multiple titles, and as a feature-film DP on several movies. His procedural cinematic and in-game camera system, Cinemachine, was acquired by Unity, where he brings his cinematic, lighting and in-game camera experience as Head of Cinematics. He holds a number of patents in the area of CG camera technology, virtual cinematography and procedural camera behavior, in addition to his wicked, out-of-control obsession with lenses, especially vintage ones.

sessions.title: Octane 2018 for Unity: Cinematic and Holographic Media on the RNDR Blockchain

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Join Jules Urbach, co-founder and CEO of OTOY, as he previews the latest release of OctaneRender, Octane 2018, and upcoming features in Unity. In this advanced session, learn more about the latest in holographic rendering and its application on OTOY's RNDR network. Jules will dive into the goals and challenges of deploying a fully decentralized GPU ray tracing and streaming platform on top of the Ethereum blockchain, as well as how future phases of RNDR will unlock modular IP rights management of holographic media and AR services.

speaker.title: Founder, CEO and Chairman
speaker.bio: Jules is the visionary and strategic mind behind OTOY's pioneering work in computer graphics, streaming, and 3D rendering. With over 25 years of industry experience, he has been revolutionizing 3D content capture, creation, and delivery through his work with OTOY and LightStage. With his latest project (RNDR), Jules is working to utilize the blockchain to push content creation and rendering further than ever before.

sessions.title: Open Match: Multiplayer Matchmaking with Unity and Google

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Matchmaking is an essential component of today's most popular multiplayer games. Unity and Google are co-leading a new open-source project designed to tackle this common and challenging aspect of multiplayer game creation. Learn how it works and how you can get involved.

speaker.title: Product Manager
speaker.bio: As the product manager leading the strategy for Gaming on the Google Cloud Platform, Micah is committed to enabling developers to realize their vision for great games. An avid gamer on all major platforms, he never hesitates to get involved in games that were built with a passion for immersive storytelling, innovative multiplayer experiences and breathtaking artwork.

speaker.title: Product Manager
speaker.bio: For many years, it's been Brandi's passion to make games that connect people in exciting and creative ways. From Bungie to Funomena, she has explored game development ranging from AAA to indie. Now Oculus to Unity, she's focused on the technology required to democratize Connected Games, so more developers can bring the online games they dream of to life.

speaker.title: Senior Software Engineer
speaker.bio: Prior to Unity, Caleb worked at Microsoft on Xbox Live, designing and developing multiplayer services, publishing systems, and on the Minecraft store. Before that, he co-founded a computer-vision startup that built virtual fitting-room technology. Outside of work, Caleb's personal projects span a range of topics, including computer vision algorithms, game design, electronics and music.

sessions.title: Optimizing AR: How to Extend Battery Life and Avoid Overheating

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Two of the biggest hurdles for handheld AR development are device overheating and drained batteries. Attend this session to learn how simple development techniques and the right editor settings can maximize battery life and maintain controlled thermal conditions for your Unity AR project. This session is appropriate for all developer levels.

speaker.title: Developer Relations Manager
speaker.bio: Adam works with Unity's Enterprise Support team as the Lead Developer-Relations Manager on Unity's Enterprise Support team,  This role has offered him the opportunity to lead support efforts for some of the most notable Made With Unity games. Prior to his time at Unity, Adam spent nearly a decade in MMORPG production and development. Adam is as much a fan of Unity as he is a part of Unity, and continues to independently develop his own Made-with-Unity games.

sessions.title: Optimizing Engagement and LTV with Personalization

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Maximizing player lifetime value (LTV) requires a fine balance between in-app purchases, ads and more. In this session, two Unity product and monetization experts will explain how Unity uses machine learning to deliver each player a unique experience that optimizes for LTV.

speaker.title: Product Director
speaker.bio: Stephen is a Director of Product Management for Unity. In this role, he oversees new product development, business strategy, and go-to-market execution for Unity's Ads and Monetization products. He was previously the Director of Product Management at Chartboost, an Executive Producer and Senior Product Manager at Zynga and Founder of the mobile gaming startup, Playnomi. Stephen holds an MBA from MIT and a BS in Computer Science and Electrical Engineering from Seattle University.

speaker.title: Product Director
speaker.bio: As a Product Director at Unity, Felix oversees the development and deployment of revenue-optimization capabilities as well as programmatic advertising. Prior to Unity, Felix served as Senior Director, Yield and Monetization at AppNexus, where he was responsible for leading the monetization team to deploy initiatives that drove overall publisher revenue growth. He previously worked as Director of Ad Revenue and Strategy at Zynga, where he was responsible for driving new initiatives to optimize overall ad yield on supply for Zynga properties across mobile, video, and desktop. Felix also has a yield management background from both the management consulting and commercial aviation industry prior to his entry into tech. Felix holds an MSE in Operations Research Engineering and BSE in Computer Science Engineering, both from the University of Michigan.

sessions.title: Pixonic's Recipe for Success – Pairing Ads & IAP in War Robots

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Vladimir Krasilnikov, Pixonic's Head of Game Design, explains how they used Unity to build War Robots, and shares their strategy of implementing video ads — without hurting IAP revenue.

speaker.title: Head of Game Design
speaker.bio: Vladimir has worked as Head of Game Design at Pixonic since 2017. For over seven years prior to that, he was involved in developing free-to-play games for social networks and mobile devices, including War Robots. He has recently begun reviewing projects for publishing with Pixonic.

sessions.title: Prefab Workflow Improvements – An Introduction

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: In this session, Nikoline, a Unity UX Designer, will explain how recent improvements to the Prefab workflows will give you more control and make you more productive while you're building your projects. For example, she'll cover editing prefabs in Prefab mode, nesting Prefabs, creating Prefab variants, and using the improved Prefab Model workflows.

speaker.title: User Experience Designer
speaker.bio: Nikoline Høgh is a User Experience Designer at Unity who focuses on creating experiences that delight, empower, and improve the lives of creative professionals. Her team's mission is to challenge the status quo and be the voice that keeps Unity innovating: pushing beyond what's good enough. She holds a master's degree in Interaction Design, specializing in creative collaboration. Previously, she contributed to the designs of a number of Unity features such as 2D Sprite Shape and Tilemap.

sessions.title: Propelling AEC to New Heights by Collaborating across Platforms with AR

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value:
In this session, you'll learn how Studio 216 used Unity to create sales & marketing real-time visualizations in mixed reality. You will see a variety of client examples that doesn't just show stunning visualizations, but how their clients collaborated in order to iterate their designs across platforms. 

Projects showcased
Microsoft retail flagship store - 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xefYrNytsPY&t=0s&list=PLdffXjtp6RqcH0xxK2qJ1CgzbakBwGYpG&index=15

Commerical Real Estate 
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCRhgnqav_vrpxOalymOEU4A
https://www.youtube.com/watch?time_continue=89&v=bbd4ME4Vpo8
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=krh76PdOrVc"

speaker.title: Chief Technology Officer
speaker.bio:
Bharat Ahluwalia is the CTO of Studio 216 and heads both the platform and services organizations within the company.  He is responsible for successful delivery of client projects and owns the road-map and development of Studio 216's flagship Altoura platform that enables collaborative visualization and design of physical spaces and provides a foundation for custom experiences for enterprises.

Prior to joining Studio 216, Bharat was part of the HoloLens Developer Platform team and nowadays he frequently curses himself while building apps on top of the same platform.

sessions.title: Rendering Techniques for Augmented Reality

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Have you ever wondered why your virtual and real-world objects look disconnected from each other? Are you curious about how to blend virtual and physical spaces to create a seamless experience? This talk will cover advanced techniques using lighting, depth masks, occlusion, shadows and more to create a sense of immersion.

speaker.title: Unity XR engineer
speaker.bio:
Lukasz Pasek works as an XR Software Engineer on the Unity Mixed Reality team in Bellevue, WA.
Prior to this, he worked at Microsoft creating experiences for Microsoft HoloLens. At home, he enjoys experimenting with HCI and studying machine learning.

sessions.title: Sample First Person Shooter Deep Dive – Graphics

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: First Person Shooter Sample is a project designed to show product-grade implementations of Unity features, including graphics and networking, in a real-time multiplayer context. In this intermediate-level session, we focus on the High-Definition Render Pipeline (HDRP), the structure of project from an art point of view.

speaker.title: Technical Art Director
speaker.bio: Martin has been making art for games for two decades, his first steps into game art were made modding the first Quake engine games and today his experience in game production spans 4 console generations. Originally starting in environment art he expanded into technical art and tool design, he previously lead the environment art team at Io Interactive (SQEX) on the Hitman series where he also collaborated on tools and rendering development. Since 2016 he has worked as Technical Art Director on Sample Games at Unity Technologies.

sessions.title: Sample First Person Shooter Deep Dive – Networking

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: A deep dive in the netcode of the fps.sample project. In this talk, we describe how the netcode of a fast-paced multiplayer shooter like the fps.sample works. We will cover snapshot generation and compression, client-side prediction and lag compensation. We will also show how the game code has been structured into a server and a client part to enable a small, dedicated server to run the game. If you plan to hack on the fps.sample project or just want to learn how this type of multiplayer works, this talk is for you!

speaker.title: Lead Programmer, Demo Team
speaker.bio: Peter leads a team of game developers at Unity who build example projects that help kick-start new games. He compares his team's function to that of a personal trainer keeping Unity fit and strong by exercising it daily. Before joining Unity, he was lead programmer on console and desktop games at studios like IO Interactive and Press Play. In his free time, Peter passes on the joys of programming to the next generation through the CoderDojo organization.

sessions.title: Scaling AAA Multiplayer Experience with Multiplay, a Unity Company

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Acquired by Unity in November 2017, Multiplay is an Enterprise Game Server Hosting Platform made for developers who want to create real-time multiplayer experiences. Join Matthew Morris and Larry Rye from Multiplay to learn how they host and operate titles that include Titanfall 2, Gang Beasts, and PUBG.

speaker.title: Lead Solutions Engineer
speaker.bio: With over 17 years' experience as an engineer in hosting and gaming, Larry works with game engineers from  around the world to design and implement game-server hosting solutions that are focused on the genre-specific gamer experiences. Learn how he and his team have overcome some of the toughest challenges in scaling multiplayer games – from 4-player co-ops to 100-player battle royale games.

speaker.title: Head of Sales
speaker.bio: Matthew heads up the Sales, Client & Solutions teams at Multiplay, a Unity company. In this role, he leads engagements with game studios around the world to plan and design robust hosting infrastructure for their multiplayer games. Matthew has over 14 years' experience in hosting and gaming and has been instrumental in driving Multiplay's reputation as the go-to game-server hosting specialist.

sessions.title: Scaling the AAA Multiplayer Experience with Multiplay

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Acquired by Unity in November 2017, Multiplay is an Enterprise Game Server Hosting Platform that enables developers to create scalable, resilient and cost-effective real-time multiplayer experiences. Join Lawrence Rye (Lead Solutions Engineer, Multiplay) in this introductory session to learn how they host and operate titles like Titanfall 2, Gang Beasts, and PUBG.

speaker.title: Lead Solutions Engineer
speaker.bio: With over 17 years' experience as an engineer in hosting and gaming, Laurence (Larry) Rye works with game engineers from all around the world to design and implement game-server hosting solutions that are focused on the genre-specific gamer experience. Learn from Larry how his team has overcome some of the toughest challenges in scaling multiplayer games from 4-player co-ops to 100-player battle royale games.

sessions.title: Shifting Gears: How to Win with AR

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: See how developers are building next-generation augmented reality experiences with model targets in Vuforia Engine to drive automotive innovation.

speaker.title: Principal Product Manager, Developer Content & Evangelism
speaker.bio: Vinny DaSilva is a Developer Evangelist at PTC for the Vuforia Engine platform. Vinny is passionate about creating AR/VR experiences in Unity. Before joining PTC, Vinny was a consultant working with a diverse set of clients in industries such as medical devices, financial services, startups, and many more. In a previous life, Vinny spent over ten years as an engineer working in the life-sciences industry. In his current role, Vinny focuses on helping developers throughout the world create great Augmented Reality experiences.

sessions.title: Sonder Case Study: How a Passionate Global Team Created a Unique Indie Short

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Sonder is a breathtaking, 13-minute film created by SOBA, a globally distributed team of former and current employees of industry-leading studios. It began as a passion project and is now accepted to nine film festivals in 2018 alone, with more to come next year. Using a 2D toon-shaded look, even though all their assets were 3D, these creators developed some sophisticated shader designs. Come hear producer Sara K. Sampson and other members of the crew go behind the scenes in the making of this highly original and poignant short film.

speaker.title: Producer
speaker.bio: Sara K. Sampson is currently producing an unannounced Netflix original animated TV series. She is also the production supervisor for two unannounced projects, which include a Netflix original short film and John Kahrs' Google Spotlight Story. Previously, she worked as production engineer at Pixar Animations Studios on features like Inside Out, Finding Dory, and Coco.

sessions.title: Sprite Rigging Workflows in 2D Animation

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Discover the new Sprite Rigging workflows for creating 2D animation in Unity. This session will explore the tools and components that come together to create a tight iteration loop for bringing your 2D characters and worlds to life.

speaker.title: Technical Product Manager, 2D
speaker.bio: Rustum (Rus) is a Product Manager for 2D in R&D at Unity. He has been making games for more than 10 years and developing in Unity almost as long. Rus owns Craft Colony, a game production and consulting company, is a games technology generalist, and takes a holistic approach to game development. He is an MSC Malaysia Intellectual Property Creators Challenge (IPCC) winner. In 2012, Rus released Penyu the Turtle, a top‐down shooter for iOS. He also launched and managed Malaysia's first online portal for game assets. Previously, he was Technical Art Director at Big Bad Robots and Senior 3D Artist at GameBrains.

sessions.title: Start Creating Shaders Visually with Shader Graph Now

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Tired of hand-coding your shaders? The Shader Graph saves you time and frustration by letting you build shaders visually. In this overview session, veteran game developer Alexandre Kikuchi will show you how to easily create and connect nodes in a graph framework, which gives you instant feedback on the changes. Shader Graph is simple enough that even new users can become involved in shader creation.

speaker.title: Tech Evangelist Latam
speaker.bio: Alex is a veteran of the game industry in Brazil, with several titles shipped under Odin (his previous company), and his most recent title, Community Inc, developed by T4 (his new company) and published by Tinybuild (check the Steam page: http://store.steampowered.com/app/631540/Community_Inc/). Before joining Unity, he was a board member of the Council of Abragames (the Brazilian Association of Game Developers). He currently spends his time learning as much as he can about game development while helping fellow creators in Latin America make amazing games and animations with Unity.

sessions.title: Stereo(scopic) 3D-180 for VR Filmmakers

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Creating a performant container app is only half the challenge of bringing great video experiences to VR – and 3D-360 isn't the answer. 3D-180 video is a new, easier way to create higher quality stereoscopic video with less effort spent on post-production. In this intermediate-level session, we'll cover best practices for creating 3D-180 video for distribution and playback in Oculus Go and other VR headsets through a live workshop. After discussing camera hardware, software tools, real-world differences between 180 and 360, spatial audio, and best practices in shooting, editing, encoding, and distribution, we will actually shoot, edit, and distribute a short video for viewing in Oculus Go.

speaker.title: Immersive Media Lead
speaker.bio: Eric is an award-winning photographer, technologist and musician who specializes in developing and applying new technologies to media and storytelling. He works as Oculus' Head of Immersive Media, and his photographic work can be found at echengphoto.com.

sessions.title: Substance PBR Materials Workflow for Real-Time Rendering

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Substance is the benchmark when it comes to creating PBR materials. In this session, Jeremie will do a deep dive into the Automotive selection available in Substance Source, showcasing how these materials are created using either a scan-based approach or fully procedural workflow. He will also show you how to texture assets using the Substance Painter LiveLink, which is available in the free Substance in Unity plugin.

speaker.title: Market Strategy Director for Entertainment
speaker.bio: Based in Los Angeles, CA, Jeremie is Allegorithmic's Market Strategy Director for Entertainment, acting as the main interface between clients in North America and Allegorithmic's development teams. He joined the company in 2006 as a technical artist, and has degrees in computer science and computer graphics.

sessions.title: Technical Deep Dive into the New Prefab System

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Take a dive deep into the new prefab features with developers Steen Lund. What's the inside versus outside of a prefab? How does it relate to Prefab mode, overrides, unpacking, and prefab variants? How has the new prefab back-end changed? This session will give you a better understanding of the Prefab system, the pros and cons of various implementation decisions, and some Aha moments working with Prefab nesting.

speaker.title: Lead Developer
speaker.bio:
Steen has been playing computer games and programming since he got a Commodore C64 as a young boy and has always known he wanted to work with games. He later got a Commodore Amiga and started writing small demos for the demo scene. The Amiga and Demo scene is still dear to him but after getting his Masters Degree games has been the main focus, only interrupted for a short time by banking software. 

Before joining Unity Steen worked on the Watchmen games at Deadline Games and Limbo at Playdead. He has now been at Unity for 7 years and has worked asset import pipeline, version control integration, multi scene editing and many other things. Currently he is leading the Scene Management team on features that will improve workflow and collaboration.

sessions.title: Testing and QA Open Mic

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Are you involved in testing or QA on projects in Unity? Richard will provide a quick overview of the state of Unity for all things testing related, and then invite you to share your stories of success, failure, pain, and glory. Learn from your fellow developers and give feedback on how Unity could help you hold your projects to a higher quality standard.

speaker.title: Senior Software Developer
speaker.bio:
Richard has been programming since age 4, and had his first game-publishing contract at age 14 (though to his knowledge, the publisher never actually sold a single copy). He has worked both on AAA games at studios such as Rebellion and on shoestring-budget indie games. Many people know him from assorted forums and chat rooms, where he has helped thousands of developers solve problems in their projects.

He has worked at Unity since late 2014, where he is involved in projects across the company, with a particular interest in problems around quality, data, philosophy, and usability. In his spare time, he composes music and experiments with food.

sessions.title: The Evolution of the ECS API

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Come take a look at the past, present, and future of the Entity Component System (ECS) API. Software engineer, Aria Bonczek from the Unity Data-Oriented Design team, will offer a few specific examples of why we made the choices we did with this API. And anyone curious about the ECS will get a good overview of the API and its standards.

speaker.title: Software Engineer
speaker.bio: Aria Bonczek has been working in the games industry since 2015. Before joining the Data-Oriented Design team at Unity, she worked as an engineer and cloth-simulation wrangler at Santa Monica Studio on the God of War franchise. She enjoys solving low-level software problems and empowering others to do the same through technology and education. Outside of work, Aria can be found at comic and gaming conventions practicing her photography and cosplaying her favorite character or playing Dungeons & Dragons and LARPing.

sessions.title: The Future of Connected Games: Unity and the Cloud

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: From connected single-player to real-time multiplayer, are you ready to explore the spectrum of connected games? Join Google Cloud Platform and Unity product managers Micah Baker and Brandi House to discover how you can use Google and Unity to build and scale games that serve a global audience.

speaker.title: Product Manager
speaker.bio: For many years, it's been Brandi's passion to make games that connect people in exciting and creative ways. From Bungie to Funomena, she has explored a breadth of games development ranging from AAA to indie. Now Oculus to Unity, she's focused on the technology required to democratize Connected Games, so more developers can bring the online games they dream of to life.

speaker.title: Product Manager
speaker.bio: As the product manager leading the strategy for gaming on the Google Cloud Platform, Micah is committed to enabling developers to realize their vision for great games. An avid gamer on all major platforms, he never hesitates to get involved in games that were built with a passion for immersive storytelling, innovative multiplayer experiences and breathtaking artwork.

sessions.title: The Next Frontier in Ad Innovation for Mobile

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Join industry and Unity experts as they discuss exciting new advertising formats, including highly engaging Augmented Reality (AR) ads. You'll learn how these innovative ad formats are changing the way both brands and games connect with their audiences and achieve the desired campaign results.

speaker.title: Senior Product Marketing Manager, Monetization
speaker.bio: Tracy is a Senior Product Marketer at Unity, working across adaptive gaming and mobile business products. She focuses on innovative product solutions for both brand advertisers and game developers.

speaker.title: VP of Experiential Technology
speaker.bio: As VP of Experiential Technology at Digitas, Keith specializes in the technologies that power innovative marketing and advertising campaigns for clients.  He has worked with iconic brands like Whirlpool, AMEX, MIllerCoors, Disney and PlayStation to develop the next generation of creative digital-technology experiences.  With a background in Production and CGI, Keith specializes in immersive technologies like AR & VR.  Meanwhile, in the Lab, Keith leads a steady stream of research and development, prototyping and experimentation to find the next innovative solution for Digitas' client partners.

sessions.title: To be revealed
To be revealed
To be revealed

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Stay tuned for more info

sessions.title: Transform your VR Experience and Expand your Audience with Mixed Reality

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: VR has emerged as one of the most innovative ways to promote and showcase content, whether it's a game, shopping experience, real estate or construction site tour or a simulation. In this session we'll talk about how using mixed reality can transform your VR experience and take it to the next level. Mixed reality allows people to see the participant in the VR experience, interacting with the VR world. Mixed reality makes your VR experience a more social and engaging experience. We've seen how much more engaged spectators are when watching people play games via mixed reality; learn how to take that same concept and apply it to other industries and use cases. MixCast by Blueprint Reality integrates easily with your Unity VR project and allows you to easily create high quality mixed reality digital pics and videos, with or without a green screen.

speaker.title: CTO and Co-Founder
speaker.bio: Ben Sheftel, CTO and Co-Founder of Blueprint Reality, has been creating video games from a young age, and has a rare cross-discipline blend of experience in 3D modelling, game design, and software engineering. Ben has been leading engine, code and tools development from the outset and rapid expansion of both the Mobile and VR markets. His work includes JEOPARDY!, Red Bull Air Race, Bike Unchained, Tiger Woods PGA Tour, and Iron Maiden: Legacy of the Beast, in addition to leading technology development in the User Experience and VR groups at previous companies. Ben’s experience with 3D art provides a robust foundation for innovation with tool and pipeline development.

speaker.title: CEO and Co-Founder
speaker.bio: Tarrnie Williams is a highly experienced, creative leader who has dedicated his career to building products on the leading edge of interactive technology. He has led development on almost every platform launch, new device, and business model, and has helped build and operate multiple successful studios and teams, including Electronic Arts Canada and Los Angeles, Relic Entertainment and Roadhouse Interactive. Tarrnie is currently the co-founder and CEO of Blueprint Reality Inc., an inter-reality media company that enables the sharing of experiences between people in the real world and the virtual world, via mixed reality.

sessions.title: Troubleshooting Memory-Related Issues with the Memory Profiler

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Finding leaking memory, the biggest memory allocations, or just poking around to see what was happening on the memory level has not always been easy, but is essential to getting the best performance for your game. Come to this session to learn how the Memory Profiler improves upon Unity's past tools and helps you troubleshoot memory issues faster.

speaker.title: Programmer
speaker.bio: Even in his early days, Greg knew that he wanted to create computer games. He started realizing his dream around 2000, when he joined his first non-profit indie group. Around the same time, he decided that what he really loves about game development is not creating games themselves but creating technology that allows others to build games they dream about. This discovery pushed him down a long and difficult path of engine development. Multiple indie and AAA game projects later, he is still passionate about his work. Since 2017, he has worked in Unity's Copenhagen office, where he focuses on C++ containers, low-level memory management, and tools to investigate memory issues.

speaker.title: Developer
speaker.bio: Stephanie is a dedicated developer who spends most of her time thinking about the future of game development. She thrives on building the next generation of technologies that will both democratize development and improve efficiency for all game developers. Over the years, she has worked in both R&D and game production on many titles in the industry as well as on her own indie game and engine project. All of which provide her with a well-rounded vision of what the future development process will require. She joined Unity in 2017 as part of the Core team and has been focusing on the new Memory Profiler tool.

sessions.title: UIElements, a new UI system for the editor

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: We have designed a new UI system (targeted for 2019.1 release) that will replace IMGUI for extending the Editor. Learn how the new system – built for performance and scalability –  will have a comprehensible and conventional API and enable designers to easily contribute to styling and layout.

speaker.title: Sr. Technical Product Manager
speaker.bio: A seasoned software development manager with more than 18 years' experience in mobile and web development, Benoit is deeply motivated by the convergence of art and technology. At Unity, which he joined in January 2018 as a technical product manager, he has drawn on his background in the mobile gaming industry to provide insight on how to improve user experience.

speaker.title: Editor Developer
speaker.bio:
Damian is a tools and API developer always aiming for code elegance, flexibility, and ease of use.

He joined Unity in June 2017 and works on the new UIElements UI framework as part of the Editor team.

Damian's background is in 3D content creation tools and APIs, in both the Games and VFX industries.

sessions.title: Unity 2019 R&D Roadmap

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Our VP of Product, Andrew Bowell, and Product Manager, Stine Kjærbøll, will take you through our roadmap for future features and enhancements in our upcoming 2018.3 release and in the upcoming 2019 cycle. Get up to speed on the latest developments in ECS, the improved prefabs workflows, terrain editor, VFX editor, connected games, and much more. You'll learn when you can expect new features and functionality to be released and also have the opportunity to ask questions.

speaker.title: Product Manager
speaker.bio: When Stine joined Unity in 2013, she was the only designer in R&D. Soon after, she was leading Unity's first UX team and later transitioned to product management, where she works closely with the core R&D team bringing a user-centered approach to software development. Stine believes it doesn't matter how advanced a technology is, if it doesn't truly serve people.

speaker.title: VP Product
speaker.bio: Andrew heads up Product for Unity R&D. Together with the incredible engineers in R&D and Unity's awesome user base, Andrew's team helps to set the direction for Unity's technology from Features to Platforms, Graphics to Core all connected to Unity's ever more powerful Developer Services. Andrew graduated from a youth of C64 and x86 fiddling and stepped foot for real into the games industry in 2000. At Havok Andrew was part of the team that got Havok Physics off the ground going on to power games like Skyrim, Halo, Assassin's Creed and Uncharted.

sessions.title: Unity for Artists: From Passion to Profession

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Unity artists are in high demand across industries, and in this session, we're going to give you some important tips for honing your Unity artist skills. We'll walk through the Unity educational resources that are available to you online. We'll also show you how you can use Unity to enhance your art and showcase your work. Finally, we'll give you some ideas for how to expand your skill set into new areas like AR and VR.

speaker.title: Student Programs Manager
speaker.bio: As the Student Programs Manager at Unity, Carl Domingo supports student communities around the world. While in college studying game development and later at Major League Hacking, he witnessed the rise of future tech leaders at hackathons all around the world. Carl has spent several years helping students and others discover their potential and empowering them to progress in their careers.

sessions.title: Unity for Educators: Free Resources for Teachers and Schools

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Unity offers a ton of free resources to schools, teachers, and students. Come learn what's available to you, how to get started teaching game development in the classroom, and how to launch your students into real-time 3D, AR, VR, and other creative content.

speaker.title: Student Ambassador Program
speaker.bio: Carl Domingo is the Student Programs Manager at Unity, working to support student communities around the world. While in college studying game development and later at Major League Hacking, he witnessed the rise of future tech leaders at hackathons all around the world. Carl has spent several years helping students and others discover their potential and empowering them to progress in their careers.

sessions.title: Unity for Film: Product Roadmap and Q&A

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: If you are or will be using Unity for film, you won't want to miss this in-depth talk from Sr. Technical Product Manager for Film, Mathieu Muller. Starting with an overview of upcoming features, enhancements, packages, templates and integrations, he'll also cover the different types of solutions Unity offers for film and animation, and finish up with a Q&A for all your burning technical questions.

speaker.title: Sr. Technical Product Manager, Film
speaker.bio: Mathieu was born between Atari2600 and Commodore64, and studied in France, Switzerland and Canada. He  worked for 13 years as a software engineer on a graphics engine for professional flight simulators and on games middleware. At Unity for four years, he travels around the world as a field engineer, visiting film and game studios.

sessions.title: Unlock the power of your BIM Data for Real-TIme Development with Unity and PiXYZ

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: This presentation will focus on the exciting uses for high resolution CAD data and in-depth look at importing into Unity with a PiXYZ plugin. We'll demonstrate how the Revit format and Rule Engine will be performed by Unity while using PiXYZ to simply the models, making it simple for developers. We'll be showing you previews of upcoming photo-realistic Unity material library specifically built for the AEC market.

speaker.title: Product Manager
speaker.bio: https://drive.google.com/open?id=1xoGzJ-6nd0EABxW8ZgqwRpN7TCv1-2vfz1dbfkarxtU

sessions.title: Unlock Your CAD Data for Real-Time Development (Unity+PiXYZ) – AEC

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: This advanced presentation will focus on the exciting uses for high-resolution BIM data and provide an in-depth look at importing into Unity with a PiXYZ plugin for AEC (architecture, engineering, and construction) projects. We'll demonstrate how the Revit format and Rule Engine will be performed by Unity while using PiXYZ to simplify the models for developers. We'll be showing you previews of the upcoming photorealistic Unity material library specifically built for the AEC market.

speaker.title: Product Manager
speaker.bio: Luc is from Montreal, Canada. Working in the movie and architectural industries for over 13 years, he has contributed to the fields of photorealistic rendering, FBX format, virtual movie sets, Unity Services and 3D content-creation tools.

speaker.title: Software Engineer
speaker.bio: Olivier is a software engineer with a mechanical and CAD background in the aircraft industry. He has experience on CAD data optimization for runtime applications with Unity. He recently joined the PiXYZ team, focusing on the integration of PiXYZ technology in game engines.

sessions.title: Using Machine Learning to enhance content production workflows - Unity Global Graduate Fellowship Seminar

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: In this session, we cover how machine learning is changing the content production workflows for creating games and real-time animation content. We present three research projects conducted by our 2017 fellowship winners including an AI-assisted level editor for designers and artists, procedural music and sound effects generation for games, and optimized methods for transfer learning of physically based character motion.

speaker.title: PhD candidate
speaker.company: UC San Diego, Department of Music
speaker.bio: Chris is a PhD candidate in the UC San Diego department of music focusing on applications of machine learning to music and audio. He is co-advised by Miller Puckette, inventor of the Max and PD audio programming environments, and Julian McAuley, a leading expert in recommender systems. Chris is also a lifelong musician and is passionate about creating tools that assist musicians in their creative pursuits.

speaker.title: PhD candidate
speaker.bio: Matthew Guzdial is a current Ph.D. candidate at Georgia Tech who researches creative machine learning, that is machine learning applied to creative domains (games, visual art, and narrative) and cognitive models of creativity applied to machine learning. His work focuses on democratizing creative authoring tools. He is a member of the Entertainment Intelligence lab at Georgia Tech under his advisor, Dr. Mark Riedl.

speaker.title: PhD student
speaker.company: MIT's Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory
speaker.bio: Andrew is a Ph.D. student at MIT's Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory co-advised by Wojciech Matusik and Daniela Rus, working on the Printable Programmable Machines project. He is creating tools to enable users to quickly design, program, and easily fabricate their own personal robots using data-driven tools. He is strongly interested in democratizing fabrication, both in form and function, and computational creativity. His work falls in the intersection of computer graphics, machine learning, and robotics.

sessions.title: Virtual Cinematography & Hollywood: The Tools Powering Ready Player One and Blade Runner 2049

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: When two veterans of the film and game industries, Wes Potter and Habib Zargarpour, joined forces to create a virtual cinematography company, they were trying to fill a void in production because directors and DPs were becoming increasingly removed from their work on CG productions. The result was Vancouver-based Digital Monarch Media (DMM), where traditional filmmaking ideologies meet real-time game-engine technology via their Virtual Film Tools suite. Their goal was to bring the creative process back into the shots on set, as if it was all practical shooting. Don't miss this live demonstration of the innovative tools used by the likes of Steven Spielberg and Denis Villeneuve!

speaker.title: CCO
speaker.bio: Habib has over 14 years of experience in visual effects for film and 14 years in the games industry. Nominated for two Academy Awards and the winner of two BAFTAs in visual effects, his recent role as Visual Effects Consultant on Blade Runner 2049, partnering with VFX Supervisor John Nelson, allowed him to make full use of his creative and visual skills on a broad scope of work. In 2016, he worked with VFX Supervisor Scott Anderson on A Series of Unfortunate Events for Netflix. Prior to that, he was Partner Director of Visuals at Microsoft Studios, responsible for visuals across all publishing titles for Xbox One, Windows, and HoloLens. Some of his other film projects include Twister, The Perfect Storm, two Star Trek films, Star Wars: Episode I, The Bourne Identity, Spawn, and Signs. Habib received a Visual Effects Society (VES) award in 2006 for Need for Speed: Most Wanted. His project RYSE: Son of Rome was a launch title for Xbox One and is still recognized as a visual showcase for the platform. He developed a real-time visualization system used by Jon Favreau and DP Bill Pope to film The Jungle Book and by Steven Spielberg on Ready Player One. Habib is also an active member of AMPAS VFX Branch, BAFTA, and a founding member of the Visual Effects Society and the 5D-Conference. He served on the executive board of the Visual Effects Branch of the Academy in 2016-17.

speaker.title: CEO
speaker.bio:
Wes is the founder and co-owner of Digital Monarch Media Ltd., a company focused on developing and
customizing virtual cinematography tools for film, TV and video games. He has spent the last seven years
working with various film projects in L.A. and London, pushing the boundaries of what can be done in virtual
productions. Among others, he has worked with Steven Spielberg's Ready Player One, Jon Favreau's
The Jungle Book, and most recently has deployed technology on Denis Villeneuve's Blade Runner
2049, and there are many more projects in the works. Prior to the motion-picture industry, Wes studied fine arts, working in oils and charcoal but ultimately incorporating his love for computers into a master's thesis utilizing real-time animation and interaction in traditional media. After university, Wes joined the video game industry as a software developer, focusing on visual effects, physics, and animation, among many other areas that sparked his interest. He was a primary developer for the Need for Speed racing franchise and worked on other products such as James Bond 007: Everything or Nothing, and Plants vs. Zombies Garden Warfare. His career in digital entertainment finally led him to Microsoft Studios and later DMM, where he joined with friends, new and old, to bring these ideas into the foundations that so many creatives are using today.

sessions.title: We Love Performance! How Tic Toc Games Uses ECS in Mobile Puzzle Games

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Tic Toc Games recently implemented Unity's Entity Component System (ECS) in their mobile puzzle engine, which brought both great performance improvements and faster iteration time. This intermediate-level session will explain why ECS is able to process data much faster, how they increased iteration speed using ECS, and their experience learning and working with Unity's ECS package.

speaker.title: Lead Programmer
speaker.bio: Garth studied mathematics at University of California, Berkeley, and has been a lead programmer at Tic Toc Games in Burbank, CA, for the last six years, where he's helped develop new IP from The Adventures of Pip, PAX 10 winner on XBLA, PSN, and Nintendo eShop, to Pug Run, a number-one-rated kids game in seven countries on iOS and Android. He's also shipped numerous licensed mobile games with millions of downloads, from Smurfs Bubble Story for Sony Pictures Television to Panda Pop for Jam City – still one of the top-grossing bubble shooters today. His passion is to combine math and technology to help development teams create engaging and entertaining products that can be enjoyed by everyone!

sessions.title: World, Film, Game: The Transmedia Storytelling of Golf Club: Wasteland

text.name: TALK_TEXT1
text.value: Golf Club: Wasteland started with the concept of a post-apocalyptic world in ruins that turned into a playground for the ultra-rich. Only after they developed the world did they design the game, story, and music videos – using the same assets and tools within the Unity framework. Closer to a virtual film set with real-time rendering, the experience across multiple media remains cohesive creatively and in terms of the pipelines for different outputs. This talk includes an overview of the development process for the latest music video from the soundtrack, followed by a look at the workflow, directing, camera scripting, and editing. Igor Simic, the creative director, will be joined on stage by Ivan Stankovic, the head programmer.

speaker.bio: Demagog studio was started informally in 2013 by high-school friends, who came together after college. Led by Igor Simić, a graduate of Columbia University, they worked on ﬁlm projects, most notably The Thinker in the Supermarket, Cost-Beneﬁt-Love and Melancholic Drone, which were awarded and screened in ﬁlm festivals and in the contemporary art context. Igor is represented by Galerie Anita Beckers in Frankfurt. A collective exhibition, Virtual Insanity, began August 3, 2018, at Kunsthalle Mainz. In the meantime, Demagog Studio created two video games as art projects, Crisis Expert, an inﬁnite runner on an economic graph, and Children's Play, a game about a factory where children make toys. The development team consists of Ivan Stanković, Miloš Milojević and Miloš Mihajlović. For Golf Club: Wasteland, the team expanded to include the architect and art director Nikola Stepković who created all the art for Golf Club: Wasteland, while Shane Berry, formerly Tokyo-based DJ and now Paris-based musician, is the sound designer and composer of the album. The company was ofﬁcially founded in 2017 with the aim to focus on ﬁlm, video, games and music.
